{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15536,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Zamia integrifolia, commonly known as coontie, prefers moderate watering routines. It is drought-tolerant once established, but for optimal growth, it requires consistently moist soil, especially during the growing season. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry, typically once per week, depending on the climate and soil drainage. Be cautious of overwatering, as it can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down. Ensure that the pot or planting area has good drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zamia integrifolia thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate full sun to partial shade conditions. In full sun, it is important that the plant receives some shade during the hottest part of the afternoon to prevent leaf burn. For indoor cultivation, place it near a window where it can receive ample light throughout the day. While it can adapt to lower light conditions, its growth may slow down, and the leaf color might not be as vibrant. Providing a balanced amount of sunlight is key to maintaining healthy and vigorous growth for this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Zamia integrifolia is generally minimal, as it naturally maintains a tidy appearance. The primary pruning task involves the removal of dead, damaged, or yellowing fronds, which helps to encourage new growth and improves the plant's overall health. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant or spreading disease. It’s best to conduct pruning during the growing season in spring or early summer. Regular removal of old foliage not only keeps the plant looking neat but also allows more light to reach new growth. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Coontie","description":"Zamia integrifolia is a small, tough, woody cycad native to the southeast United States (Florida, Georgia), the Bahamas, Cuba, Grand Cayman and possibly extinct in Puerto Rico and Haiti.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Bahamas","Cuba"],"other_name":["Coontie"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Zamia integrifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14840,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Morus nigra, commonly known as black mulberry, thrives with consistent moisture, especially during its growing season. The soil should be kept evenly moist but not waterlogged. During the warmer months, regular watering—about once or twice a week, depending on climate and soil drainage—is recommended to aid fruit development and maintain foliage health. In cooler months or if grown in colder climates, reduce watering frequency, allowing the soil's surface to dry out slightly between waterings. Always adjust watering to suit the prevailing weather conditions and ensure good drainage to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Black mulberries prefer full sunlight for optimal growth and fruit production. Ideally, they should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. While they can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in reduced fruiting and leggy growth. Ensure the planting site is not too shaded by taller trees or structures, as this will impact the mulberry’s productivity. If growing in hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch but generally, full sun exposure is required for the healthiest, most productive plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Morus nigra is essential for maintaining plant health, controlling size, and promoting a good shape. The best time to prune is late winter, just before the tree resumes growth in spring. Begin by removing any dead, damaged or diseased branches to allow for good air circulation. Then, trim back excessive growth to maintain a balanced shape and encourage fruit production on new wood. Avoid heavy pruning as it may reduce fruit yield; instead, perform light annual pruning to manage size and encourage the growth of new fruit-bearing branches."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"black mulberry","description":"Morus nigra, called black mulberry or blackberry (not to be confused with the blackberries which are various species of Rubus), is a species of flowering plant in the family Moraceae, native to southwestern Asia, where it has been cultivated for so long that its precise natural range is unknown. It is known for its large number of chromosomes, as it has 154 pairs (308 individuals). Other mulberry species are sometimes confused with black mulberry, particularly black-fruited...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western Asia","Iran","Turkey"],"other_name":["black mulberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Morus nigra"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is drought-tolerant once established but benefits from regular waterings during prolonged dry periods. Water the plant thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the soil drains well. During warmer months, you may need to water more frequently, while in cooler months, you can reduce the watering schedule. Always check the moisture level of the soil before watering to avoid excessive moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dietes bicolor prefers a location with full sun to partial shade. It thrives in a sunny spot where it gets at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, which encourages robust growth and abundant flowering. However, it can also tolerate some shade, making it versatile for various garden settings. In extremely hot climates, providing light afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching. If planted indoors or in a less sunny spot, ensure it gets bright, indirect light for optimal growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dietes bicolor is straightforward and mainly involves removing spent flower stalks and dead or damaged leaves. After flowering, cut back the flower stalks to the base to encourage new growth. Trim away any yellow or brown leaves to maintain the plant’s appearance and health. It's also beneficial to thin out the clump of plants occasionally to allow for better air circulation and to prevent overcrowding. Regular pruning helps keep the plant tidy and promotes more vigorous flowering in the coming seasons."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Yellow Fortnight Lily","description":"Dietes bicolor (variously known as African iris or Fortnight lily) is a clump-forming rhizomatous perennial plant with long sword-like pale-green leaves, growing from multiple fans at the base of the clump. This species belongs to the Iridaceae (Iris) family. It can form large clumps if left undisturbed for years. This species is common in horticulture in its native South Africa, where it is often used in public gardens, beautification of commercial premises and along roadsides.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Yellow Fortnight Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Dietes bicolor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While it can tolerate some direct morning sun, it should be shielded from harsh afternoon sunlight, as this can scorch the leaves. If growing indoors, placing the plant near a north or east-facing window that receives filtered light is ideal. In its natural habitat, it often grows under the dappled light of trees, so replicating these conditions will help the plant flourish. Insufficient light may result in reduced flowering and slower growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Scadoxus puniceus primarily involves removing dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and appearance. You can do this by simply cutting back the leaves at the base with a sharp, sterile knife or pair of scissors. Pruning is ideally done during the plant’s dormant period in late fall or winter when growth has slowed. Avoid heavy pruning, as the plant doesn’t require it to thrive, and excessive leaf removal can stress the plant unnecessarily."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Paintbrush lily","description":"Scadoxus puniceus, commonly known as the paintbrush lily, is a species of bulbous plant. It is native to much of southern and eastern Africa: Ethiopia, Sudan, Tanzania, Malawi, Mozambique, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Swaziland, and South Africa (the Cape Provinces, KwaZulu-Natal, the Free State and the Northern Provinces). Scadoxus puniceus can be found in cool, shady habitat such as ravines and forests, where it is often found in moist leaf litter. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15040,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rudbeckia maxima, commonly known as giant coneflower, prefers moderately moist soil but can tolerate short periods of drought once established. It's important to water young plants regularly to help them establish deep roots. Water deeply, ensuring the soil is moist but not waterlogged, and allow the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. During hot and dry periods, increase the frequency of watering to keep the plant healthy. Avoid overhead watering to minimize the risk of fungal diseases, and water in the morning or early afternoon so that excess moisture can evaporate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rudbeckia maxima thrives in full sun, which is essential for optimal growth and flowering. Aim to provide at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced flowering and leggy growth. In areas with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Ensure the planting site is open and receives ample sunlight throughout the day to encourage vibrant blooms and sturdy foliage. Proper sunlight exposure also supports the plant's natural resistance to pests."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rudbeckia maxima is relatively straightforward and should be performed to encourage a tidy plant and promote flowering. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to clean up the plant. After the flowering period, you can deadhead spent blooms to extend flowering and improve the plant's appearance. However, leaving some seed heads can provide food for birds and add winter interest to the garden. In late fall or early winter, cut back the plant's foliage to a few inches above the ground. This helps reduce diseases and prepares the plant for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"great coneflower","description":"Rudbeckia maxima, the great coneflower, is a flowering plant in the Asteraceae family, which is used like an ornamental plant. They can reach a maximum height of eight feet. Water the plant moderately, ensuring the soil remains consistently damp but not soggy. Avoid waterlogging, as this can cause root rot. During its dormant period in late summer and fall, reduce watering significantly. In natural settings, these plants often rely on rain, so in a garden environment, mimic these conditions by checking the soil moisture level regularly and adjusting your watering frequency accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Claytonia virginica prefers partial to full shade conditions, as it naturally grows in woodland areas under the canopy of deciduous trees. In the wild, they receive ample light during the early spring before the trees fully leaf out, making dappled sunlight or full morning light ideal. Avoid placing them in full sun, especially in hotter climates, as this can scorch the delicate leaves and reduce flowering. For optimal growth in a garden setting, select a site that mimics its natural habitat, providing shelter from harsh afternoon sun while allowing for some bright light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Claytonia virginica is minimal and generally involves cleaning up dead foliage or spent flowers to maintain plant health and appearance. After the flowering period, it's advisable to remove dead blossoms to prevent seed formation unless you want the plant to self-seed. Additionally, in late spring, once the leaves turn yellow and start dying back, you can gently clear them away to make room for new growth the following spring. Be cautious not to damage the underground corms, which store nutrients for the plant’s next growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Virginia Springbeauty","description":"Claytonia virginica, the Virginia springbeauty, eastern spring beauty, grass-flower or fairy spud, is an herbaceous perennial in the family Montiaceae. However, it’s crucial to avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. The best approach is to maintain evenly moist conditions, keeping the soil slightly damp but not soggy. During the growing season, increase watering frequency, and in winter, reduce watering accordingly. Always check the top inch of the soil; if it feels dry, it’s time to water. Consider using rainwater or distilled water to avoid the lime buildup that can occur with tap water, which is detrimental to the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron ferrugineum thrives in partial shade to dappled sunlight conditions. It prefers an environment that offers protection from harsh midday sun, which can scorch its leaves. Ideally, this plant should receive early morning sunlight or late afternoon light to simulate its natural alpine habitat. Too much direct sunlight may cause leaf burn and stress, while too little light can hinder blooming. Therefore, planting in an area with filtered light or in the shade of taller trees where it receives indirect sunlight will provide the best results for this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhododendron ferrugineum should be done minimally and usually right after it blooms in late spring. This is because rhododendrons set their flower buds for the next year very soon after flowering. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood to maintain plant health and shape. If reshaping or reducing size is necessary, do so sparingly to avoid removing next year’s blooms. Always make clean cuts with sharp pruners above a leaf node to encourage healthy growth. For older plants, consider removing a few of the oldest stems at their base to encourage new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rusty-leaved Alpenrose","description":"Rhododendron ferrugineum (sometimes called alpenrose, snow-rose, or rusty-leaved alpenrose) is an evergreen shrub that grows just above the tree line in the Alps, Pyrenees, Jura and northern Apennines, on acid soils. It is the type species for the Rhododendron genus. It may grow up to 1 m tall and produces clusters of pinkish-red, bell-shaped flowers throughout the summer. The undersides of the leaves are covered in rust-brown spots, which give the species the second part of its...","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Alps","Pyrenees"],"other_name":["Rusty-leaved Alpenrose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron ferrugineum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14544,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"While Sceptridium dissectum, commonly known as the Cutleaf Grape Fern, does not require constant watering, it is important to maintain a consistently moist environment. Water this plant moderately, ensuring the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. It's best to let the top inch of the soil dry out slightly between waterings. During dry spells or in interior spaces where the air can be drier, consider increasing the frequency of watering or using a humidity tray to maintain adequate moisture. Always check the soil moisture level to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sceptridium dissectum thrives in partial to full shade conditions, replicating its natural habitat of woodland understories. It prefers indirect sunlight and can suffer if exposed to direct, harsh sunlight for prolonged periods, which may scorch its delicate fronds. If growing indoors, place it near an east or north-facing window where it will receive gentle morning light. If outdoors, select a location under trees or in an area that receives filtered sunlight through the day. Adjust its position according to seasonal changes to ensure it does not receive too much direct light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Sceptridium dissectum generally requires minimal pruning. However, to maintain its health and appearance, you should remove any dead or damaged fronds regularly. This will encourage new growth and prevent the spread of disease. Prune in early spring before new growth begins or in late fall after the fronds have died back. Ensure you use clean, sharp scissors or gardening shears to avoid tearing the delicate fronds. It's also beneficial to occasionally thin out crowded sections to improve air circulation and promote vigorous growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cutleaf Grapefern","description":"Sceptridium dissectum is a common fern (or fern-ally) in the family Ophioglossaceae, occurring in eastern North America. Like other plants in this group, it normally only sends up one frond per year. It has long been the subject of confusion because the frond presents in one of two forms, either the normal form (forma obliquum) that resembles other plants in the genus, or the skeletonized form (forma dissectum).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Cutleaf Grapefern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Sceptridium dissectum"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15638,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tillandsia ionantha is an air plant, which means it absorbs moisture and nutrients through its leaves rather than roots in soil. To properly water this plant, mist it thoroughly 2 to 3 times a week, ensuring all the leaves are moistened. Alternatively, you can soak the entire plant in water for about 20-30 minutes once a week, allowing it to dry completely in a well-ventilated area afterward. Be cautious of water pooling in the center of the plant to prevent rot, especially in humid environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tillandsia ionantha thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight, especially during the intense midday hours, can damage the leaves by causing them to scorch. If grown indoors, place the plant near a window with filtered light, like a north or east-facing window. Outdoor positioning should ensure that the plant is protected by partial shade. In conditions where sufficient natural light isn't available, artificial fluorescent lighting can substitute, but it's crucial to avoid excess or insufficient light exposure to maintain its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is minimal for Tillandsia ionantha. Since air plants do not grow roots like typical plants, most attention to pruning involves removing dried or dead leaves, which can occur at the plant's base or tips. Use sanitized scissors to remove these parts, ensuring a clean cut. These plants will naturally propagate by producing offsets or 'pups' after blooming. Once pups are a third the size of the parent, they can be gently pulled apart to promote airflow and avoid crowding, enhancing their shape and health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Blushing Bride Airplant","description":"Tillandsia ionantha, the sky plant, is a species in the genus Tillandsia. This species is native to Central America and Mexico. It is also reportedly naturalized in Broward County, Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Blushing Bride Airplant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Offset Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Tillandsia ionantha"],"soil":["None required as plant doesn't need soil"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14841,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clematis columbiana prefers consistent moisture, especially during the growing season. Water deeply once a week, allowing the soil to partially dry out between waterings, but take care not to let it dry completely as these plants do not tolerate drought well. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. Reduce watering during the fall and winter as the plant enters dormancy, ensuring the soil is never soggy to prevent root rot. Adjust your watering schedule based on outdoor conditions, increasing frequency in hot, dry weather and reducing it during rainy periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clematis columbiana thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering. However, in hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense heat. The roots should be kept cool, so consider planting where the base of the plant receives shade or use mulch to cover the root zone. If planted in too much shade, the plant may grow but will produce fewer flowers, so balance is key based on your local climate and garden exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Clematis columbiana should be done to maintain the plant's shape and encourage healthy growth. As it flowers on the previous year's growth, prune lightly each spring to remove any dead or weak stems, cutting back to healthy buds. Avoid heavy pruning which could reduce flowering. After blooming, a light trim can help control the size and shape of the plant. Make sure to use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent disease spread. Regularly check and remove any dead or diseased parts throughout the season to keep the vine healthy and vigorous."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"blue clematis","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["blue clematis"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Clematis columbiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14545,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Woodsia ilvensis, commonly known as the rusty woodsia or oblong woodsia, prefers consistent moisture but should not sit in soggy soil. It thrives in well-drained, slightly acidic soils and benefits from regular watering during dry spells, especially in its active growing season (spring and summer). However, be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Allow the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings to ensure that the plant remains healthy. In the winter, reduce watering as the plant enters a dormant phase and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Woodsia ilvensis thrives in partial to full shade environments, emulating its native woodland habitats. It prefers dappled sunlight, making it ideal for a north or east-facing location where it can receive indirect light throughout the day. Avoid placing it in direct, harsh sunlight as this can scorch its delicate fronds and lead to dehydration. In more northern latitudes, it might tolerate some morning sun, but care should be taken to ensure it's shaded from the harsh midday and afternoon rays. Providing the right balance of light will help maintain its vibrant green appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Woodsia ilvensis involves removing dead or damaged fronds to promote healthy new growth. This is best done in the early spring before the plant begins actively growing for the season. Trim back any brown or withered fronds at their base using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. Regularly removing old fronds will encourage the fern to focus its energy on producing new, vibrant foliage. Additionally, periodic pruning helps maintain the plant's shape and promotes better airflow around the foliage, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"rusty woodsia","description":"Woodsia ilvensis, commonly known as oblong woodsia, is a fern found in North America and northern Eurasia. Trim back the plant in early spring before new growth begins, cutting back old stems to about 6 inches from the base. This encourages healthy new growth and flowering. After the flowering period ends, you may deadhead spent blooms to prevent self-seeding, though the interesting seed pods can also be left for winter interest. Maintain a neat appearance by removing any damaged stems throughout the growing season. Minimal pruning is usually sufficient for this hardy perennial."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Downy Skullcap","description":"Scutellaria incana, the hoary skullcap or downy skullcap, is a flowering plant in the family Lamiaceae and is native to North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14646,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clavulinopsis sulcata is a terrestrial fungal species, part of the coral fungi group, and does not require watering like typical plants since it absorbs moisture naturally from the environment. Ideally, maintain a high humidity level to emulate its natural conditions. If growing in a terrarium, misting occasionally might be beneficial to keep the humidity consistent."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clavulinopsis sulcata typically grows in shaded or semi-shaded forest environments, which means it does not require direct sunlight. When cultivating this fungi, position it in a spot that receives indirect light, or under artificial lighting that simulates a low-light forest floor environment. Excessive direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and the fungal bodies, leading to desiccation. It prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season and in periods of extended drought. To ensure optimal growth, water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Avoid overhead watering which can promote mildew; instead, water at ground level to keep the foliage dry. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox paniculata thrives best in full sunlight, receiving at least 6 hours of direct sun daily. Morning sun paired with afternoon shade can be beneficial, preventing the plant from overheating while ensuring it gets sufficient light for floral production. In shaded conditions, the plant may grow leggy and produce fewer blooms, so choose the planting location wisely to maximize its flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox paniculata is crucial for maintaining its health and appearance. Deadhead spent blooms throughout the growing season to encourage continuous flowering and prevent seed formation. In early spring, cut back the stems to encourage bushier growth and remove any dead or diseased wood. After the first frost, cut the plant back to the ground to tidy the garden and prepare the plant for winter dormancy. Regular pruning also helps improve air circulation, reducing the risk of powdery mildew."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"fall phlox","description":"Phlox paniculata (fall phlox, garden phlox, perennial phlox or summer phlox) is a species of flowering plant in the family Polemoniaceae, native to the eastern and central United States and eastern Canada. Generally, water sparingly during the growing season and provide less water during winter when the tree is dormant. Ensure the soil is not waterlogged to maintain a healthy root system. It originates from mountain areas where it receives ample light, so it is well-adapted to bright conditions. When planting, choose a location that provides enough sunlight throughout the day, avoiding shaded areas that might stunt growth. In less sunny environments, consider positioning it in the sunniest spot available, and ensure it doesn't face competition for light from taller structures or other plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pinus taiwanensis should be done sparingly since it naturally develops a pleasing shape. Focus on removing dead or diseased branches to promote better air circulation and growth. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Avoid heavy pruning or cutting back more than one-third of the tree's foliage at once to prevent stress. Training young trees with gentle pruning can help develop strong branch structures. Regular removal of small, interior branches can help maintain the plant's health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Taiwan red pine","description":"Pinus taiwanensis, the Taiwan red pine, is a species of conifer in the Pinaceae family. In late fall or early winter, you can cut back the plant to tidy up the appearance and prepare it for the next growing season. It requires consistent moisture but is also drought tolerant once established. During the plant's active growing season in spring and summer, it is important to water it regularly, ensuring that the soil is kept slightly moist but not waterlogged. In contrast, during the fall and winter, you can reduce the watering frequency as the plant's growth slows down, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it may lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Creeping Barberry thrives in a variety of sunlight conditions but ideally prefers partial shade. It can tolerate full sun, particularly in cooler climates, but in regions with intense, hot summers, providing some afternoon shade is beneficial to prevent leaf scorch and stress. If planted in a mostly shaded area, the plant might produce fewer flowers and berries, which are not critical from a foliage perspective. Therefore, a balance, such as dappled sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade, is optimal to keep this plant healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Berberis repens is not overly demanding, as this plant generally maintains a low-growing, spreading habit. Pruning should be done mainly to shape the plant or control its size, ideally after it has finished blooming in late spring or early summer. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and encourage healthy growth. Additionally, trimming back excessively long stems can help maintain a neat and tidy appearance. Avoid heavy pruning as the plant naturally produces a dense, attractive foliage cover."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"creeping mahonia","description":"Mahonia repens commonly known as creeping mahonia, creeping Oregon grape, creeping barberry, or prostrate barberry, is a species of Mahonia native to the Rocky Mountains and westward areas of North America, from British Columbia and Alberta in the north through Arizona and New Mexico, then into northwest Mexico by some reports. It is also found in many areas of California and the Great Basin region in Nevada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["creeping mahonia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Berberis repens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14446,"attracts":["Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Frangula caroliniana, also known as Carolina buckthorn, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, to maintain its natural habitat conditions. While it does tolerate some drought, prolonged dry periods can stress the plant. Ensure that the soil is not waterlogged; a good rule of thumb is to water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the first year post-planting, ensure it receives ample water to establish a robust root system, after which it may be more tolerant of infrequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carolina buckthorn thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide a location where the plant receives at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight daily. While it is versatile enough to tolerate some shade, full sun conditions will encourage more prolific flowering and fruiting. If growing in an area mostly shaded, ensure it is near enough to natural light to prevent it from becoming overly leggy, which can result in a weaker structure. Monitor its growth and adjust the lighting conditions if needed to ensure health and vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Frangula caroliniana, or Carolina buckthorn, minimal pruning is typically required. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins to shape the plant or remove dead and diseased branches. This is best done to maintain the desired size and shape or to remove congested growth inside the plant. Regular pruning can also promote a bushier habit and increase airflow through the plant, which helps reduce the likelihood of disease. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant and lead to reduced flowering and fruiting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina buckthorn","description":"Frangula caroliniana, commonly called the Carolina buckthorn, is a deciduous upright shrub or small tree native to the southeastern, south-central, and mid-western parts of the United States, from Texas east to Florida and north as far as Maryland, Ohio, Missouri, and Oklahoma. There is also an isolated population in the State of Nuevo León in northeastern Mexico. It is found in a wide variety of habitats, including barrens, forests, and limestone bluffs.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Carolina buckthorn"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Frangula caroliniana"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Reduce watering frequency in the fall and winter to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Ensure the planting area has good drainage, as standing water can be detrimental to the plant's health. Ideally, it should receive around 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. While it can tolerate shade, the plant may produce fewer flowers in low-light conditions. If planted indoors, placing it near a south or west-facing window can provide adequate light. Gradually acclimate the plant to increasing light levels to prevent sunburn on the leaves. Regular exposure to sunlight ensures more vibrant and prolific blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Dietes iridioides involves removing dead or damaged foliage and spent flower stalks to maintain its appearance and encourage new growth. Flower stalks should be cut back to the base after blooming. Remove any yellow or brown leaves by trimming them at the plant's base. Pruning can be done throughout the growing season, but major maintenance is best done in early spring before new growth begins. This will help in keeping the plant tidy and prevent the spread of diseases. Be sure to use sharp, clean tools to avoid injuring the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Small Fortnight Lily","description":"Dietes iridioides (African iris, Cape iris, fortnight lily, Morea iris, wild iris, dietes) is an ornamental plant in the Iridaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Small Fortnight Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Dietes iridioides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14347,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mimetes fimbriifolius is a plant native to the nutrient-poor soils of South Africa, where it has adapted to survive with minimal water. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, which can occur in overly moist conditions. During the growing season in spring and summer, water more regularly—approximately once every 7 to 10 days, depending on the ambient temperature and humidity. In the cooler months, reduce watering to once every two weeks or when the soil feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mimetes fimbriifolius thrives in environments that offer full sun exposure. If kept indoors or in cooler climates, ensure it has a place near a bright, south-facing window, supplemented with artificial grow lights if natural light is insufficient."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Mimetes fimbriifolius should be done sparingly to maintain a natural shape and encourage healthy growth. Ideally, prune in late winter or early spring before the onset of new growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant and inhibit flowering. Instead, focus on light maintenance and thinning of crowded areas to maintain the plant's aesthetic form. To encourage bushier growth, pinch out the tips of young shoots gently."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tree pagoda-bush","description":"Mimetes fimbriifolius, also called cowl pagoda or the fringed pagoda, is a species of plant in the family Proteaceae. Remove any dead, diseased, or broken branches immediately, and consider cutting back any errant limbs that disrupt the desired shape of the tree. Avoid cutting into old wood (beyond the green foliage), as this may not regenerate, potentially leading to bare patches. Light trimming annually can help maintain its compact and neat form."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Chinese arborvitae","description":"Platycladus is a distinct genus of evergreen coniferous tree in the cypress family Cupressaceae, containing only one species, Platycladus orientalis, also known as Chinese thuja, Oriental arborvitae, Chinese arborvitae, biota or oriental thuja. It is native to northwestern China, Korea, and the Russian Far East (Amur + Khabarovsk). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15936,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cornus sanguinea, commonly known as \"bloodtwig dogwood,\" requires consistent moisture, particularly in its first year or two for roots to establish. Water deeply once a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During summer, increase watering frequency to ensure the soil remains moderately moist, but avoid waterlogging as this can lead to root rot. Once established, it tolerates some drought conditions, although regular watering will promote faster growth and more vigorous stems. Mulch to conserve moisture and maintain even soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cornus sanguinea thrives in full sun to partial shade, with more intense sunlight promoting the development of its iconic vibrant stems. It is tolerant of a range of light conditions but tends to have the best color when exposed to a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight a day. In shadier spots, the growth may lean more heavily towards green foliage rather than the striking red stems. When planted in hotter climates, it will appreciate some relief from the blistering afternoon sun to prevent leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cornus sanguinea helps maintain its shape, encourages vibrant stem color, and stimulates new growth. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring, before new growth begins. Remove one-third of the oldest stems at the base to encourage new shoots with brighter bark. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15243,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hydrangea arborescens, commonly known as smooth hydrangea, requires consistent moisture to thrive. It is essential to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Water your hydrangeas deeply once or twice a week, particularly during dry spells or hot weather periods. Make sure the soil drains well, as sitting in water can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. Be vigilant about watering during the plant's active growing season in spring and summer, and reduce watering in fall and winter when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Smooth hydrangeas prefer partial sun to partial shade, ideally receiving around 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. Morning sun is preferable as the intensity is less harsh, reducing the risk of leaf scorch. In hotter climates, providing afternoon shade is beneficial to protect the plant from extreme heat. If planted in too deep a shade, the hydrangea may not flower well and can become leggy. Adjust the location or provide adequate canopy to ensure they receive just the right amount of light for healthy growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hydrangea arborescens is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This species blooms on new wood, so you can cut the stems back hard to promote vigorous growth and abundant flowering. Typically, you can prune the stems to about 12-18 inches above the ground, encouraging robust growth and larger flowers during the blooming season. Remove any dead, damaged, or weak stems to improve the plant’s shape and airflow. Regular pruning will help maintain an attractive form and enhance flowering in the coming season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wild hydrangea","description":"Hydrangea arborescens, commonly known as smooth hydrangea, wild hydrangea, or sevenbark, is a species of flowering plant in the family Hydrangeaceae. During the growing season in spring and summer, the plant may need more frequent watering. Reduce the amount in fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. It's important to find a balance to suit its specific location and ensure optimal sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geranium seemannii helps maintain a bushy shape and encourages healthy growth. Maintaining cleanliness of the cutting tools is crucial to prevent diseases. Trim away any damaged or discolored leaves as needed to maintain the plant's appearance and to reduce the risk of disease. When cultivated in less naturally moist environments, it's important to ensure the soil remains slightly damp, particularly during dry periods. During the growing season, water deeply once a week, allowing the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. It's crucial not to overwater, as pond pines do not tolerate standing water around their roots for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus serotina grows best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to thrive. This sunlight exposure is essential for optimal growth, cone production, and overall health. Partial shade can be tolerated, but diminished light can lead to slower growth and a less robust tree structure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus serotina should be done lightly and primarily for the removal of dead or damaged branches to maintain tree health and appearance. The preferred time for pruning is late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Avoid pruning in late summer or fall, as this can stimulate new growth that will not harden off before winter, making it susceptible to damage. Since this species naturally has an open, irregular crown, minimal pruning is needed. Maintaining the natural form is usually best, so only prune to alter the shape or size if absolutely necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pond pine","description":"Pinus serotina, the pond pine, marsh pine or pocosin pine, is a tree found along the Southeastern portion of the Atlantic coastal plain of the United States, from southern New Jersey south to Florida and west to southern Alabama. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14448,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Laetiporus gilbertsonii, also known as the chicken of the woods fungus, does not have specific watering requirements like typical houseplants because it is a fungus found growing naturally on tree trunks and stumps. If attempting to cultivate this fungus for consumption or study, maintaining a consistently damp environment like a humid substrate or allowing natural rainfall is essential. Avoid over-saturating the growing medium to prevent mold or other fungal competitors. Ensure good ventilation and moderate humidity conditions to mimic its natural ecosystem."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laetiporus gilbertsonii typically grows on trees and prefers shaded or partially shaded conditions in its natural habitat. While cultivating this fungus, replicate its natural growing conditions by providing indirect light or dappled shade. Direct sunlight is not necessary and can dry out the fungus or its substrate too quickly. Ensuring that this fungus is not exposed to harsh lighting conditions will help maintain the correct moisture levels and temperature balance essential for its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning does not typically apply to Laetiporus gilbertsonii in the same way it does for plants. However, if you are cultivating this fungus, it is important to regularly inspect the fruiting bodies for any signs of decay or mold and remove them to prevent spoilage and contamination. Harvest the fungus when it is young and tender for the best quality, as older specimens can become tough. Regularly clear dead or decaying mushrooms to maintain a healthy growing environment and discourage pests."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Hardwood Sulphur Shelf","description":"Laetiporus gilbertsonii is a species of polypore fungus in the family Fomitopsidaceae. It is found in western North America. It is not suited for deep shade, which can stunt its growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Meriania nobilis involves removing dead or diseased branches to promote healthy growth and maintain its attractive shape. Pruning should ideally be done in the late winter or early spring before the plant starts its active growth phase. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, which helps prevent the spread of disease. Additionally, remove any crossing branches to improve airflow within the canopy. Controlling its height and encouraging bushier growth can also be achieved through regular tip pruning. After the plant has finished flowering, you can cut back the stems to encourage new growth and potentially a second bloom. In late autumn, cutting back the plant to ground level helps clean it up for the winter and can encourage healthy new growth in the spring."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"spring vetch","description":"Lathyrus vernus (spring vetchling, spring pea, or spring vetch) is a species of flowering herbaceous perennial plant in the genus Lathyrus, native to forests of Europe and Siberia. It is adapted to open prairies and meadows, so a bright and sunny spot will closely mimic its natural habitat. If planted in partial shade, it may experience reduced vigor and fewer blooms. Therefore, choosing a location with ample exposure to sunlight will yield the best results for this plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Desmanthus illinoensis is generally minimal, focusing on maintaining shape and encouraging bushier growth. Prune the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This primarily involves cutting back dead or damaged stems to promote healthy development and to remove any unsightly bits. Additionally, regular removal of spent flowers can prevent excessive seed spreading if that is not desired and can also encourage the plant to produce more blooms. Always use clean, sharp tools to perform any cuts to minimize the risk of disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Illinois bundleflower","description":"Desmanthus illinoensis (commonly known as Illinois bundleflower, prairie-mimosa or prickleweed) is a common plant in many areas of the south central and Midwestern US. During its growing season, which is in the spring and summer, it should be watered regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce the watering frequency in the fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. It's important to let the top inch of the soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, particularly in areas with high humidity. Always use well-drained soil to avoid standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lonicera hirsuta thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. If planted in an area with too much shade, the plant may not flower as prolifically and could become leggy or spindly. In hotter climates, providing afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive heat and dehydration. Ensure the location has good air circulation to prevent fungal issues commonly found in more humid, shaded conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lonicera hirsuta is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This plant can benefit from regular pruning to maintain its shape and stimulate healthy growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to open up the plant to more sunlight and air circulation. You can also trim back overgrown or sprawling stems to keep the plant compact and tidy. Avoid heavy pruning in late summer or fall, as this can reduce the number of blooms in the following spring and summer."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hairy honeysuckle","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["hairy honeysuckle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Lonicera hirsuta"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15147,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lyonia lucida, commonly known as fetterbush, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. This plant thrives in swampy areas, so it can tolerate wetter conditions than many other shrubs. During the growing season, water regularly to maintain consistent moisture, especially in dry spells. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot. In container settings, check the topsoil to ensure it remains slightly damp, watering when it begins to dry out. Over the winter months, watering can be reduced as the plant enters dormancy, but do not allow it to dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lyonia lucida thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should get about four to six hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with very hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and stress. This adaptability allows it to grow well under the dappled sunlight of pine woods or the edges of forested areas. However, if planted in too much shade, its flowering might reduce. When situating the plant, consider the local climate and adjust sunlight exposure accordingly to ensure optimal growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lyonia lucida is often necessary to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or diseased branches with clean, sharp pruners. Thinning out crowded areas will improve air circulation within the plant. Additionally, you can trim back any particularly lengthy or unruly stems to promote a more compact and aesthetically pleasing form. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15743,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fagopyrum esculentum, commonly known as buckwheat, requires moderate watering to thrive. It's essential to maintain consistently moist soil without making it waterlogged. During the growing season, regular watering is needed to keep the soil from drying out completely. It's especially crucial during flowering and seed development stages when the plant demands more water. However, overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. A good practice is to water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch, ensuring proper drainage is in place."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Buckwheat prefers full sunlight for optimal growth, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day. This light exposure ensures proper flowering and seed production. While buckwheat can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight may result in spindly growth and reduced yields. It's beneficial to plant buckwheat in an open area where it can receive unobstructed sunlight throughout the day. During the hottest parts of summer, some afternoon shade can help prevent stress in exceedingly hot climates, but generally, full sunlight is ideal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Buckwheat does not typically require extensive pruning. However, removing dead or damaged leaves can help maintain plant health and aesthetics. Pruning can also involve removing any weeds that may compete for resources, allowing the buckwheat to flourish. Once the plant has matured and seeds have been harvested, you can cut back the remaining plant material to encourage regrowth or prepare the area for future planting. This process helps in controlling plant size and encourages a more bushy growth if desired."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Buckwheat","description":"Buckwheat (Fagopyrum esculentum), also known as common buckwheat, Japanese buckwheat and silverhull buckwheat, is a plant cultivated for its grain-like seeds and as a cover crop. A related and more bitter species, Fagopyrum tataricum, a domesticated food plant common in Asia, but not as common in Europe or North America, is also referred to as buckwheat.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China"],"other_name":["Common Buckwheat"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Fagopyrum esculentum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14449,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Morchella elata, or the black morel, is a type of wild mushroom that thrives in moist environments. While they don't require watering like typical houseplants, maintaining humidity in their growing area is key if you're cultivating them indoors. Mist the substrate to keep it slightly damp, ensuring that it never dries out completely. Over-watering can lead to mold or rot issues, so balance is crucial. In natural environments, they rely on seasonal rainfalls, so replicate that with careful misting. Monitor the substrate for any signs of excessive drying or waterlogging and adjust your misting accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"As a fungus, Morchella elata does not require direct sunlight but thrives in dappled, indirect light when cultivated. If growing in a controlled indoor setting, simulate a forest or woodland shade environment. Natural variation in light is beneficial, so having some indirect and low-level light is ideal. Too much direct sunlight can dry out their substrate and harm fruiting bodies, while total darkness might impede growth. If using artificial light, choose low-wattage to create an environment similar to their natural, shaded, forest-floor habitat for optimal results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isn't relevant for Morchella elata as it is for typical plants since they are fungi. However, when the morels fruit, you can 'prune' them by gently harvesting. Use a knife to trim the mushroom at the base rather than pulling it out, which helps protect future growth. After harvesting, keep the environment clean to prevent any leftover debris from developing mold, which could harm the next batch of morels. Collect any remaining fragments gently and dispose of them to maintain cleanliness in the growing area, facilitating healthy future yields."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Black Morel","description":"Morchella elata is a species of fungus in the family Morchellaceae. It is one of many related species commonly known as black morels, and until 2012 the name M. elata was broadly applied to black morels throughout the globe. Like most members of the genus, M. elata is a popular edible fungus and is sought by many mushroom hunters.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Black Morel"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Morchella elata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy","Rich in organic matter"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15045,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crinum americanum, commonly known as the swamp lily, thrives in consistently moist to wet environments. Ensure the soil is well-drained but retains some moisture. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, water the plant frequently to keep the soil moist. In drier periods, increase watering to maintain adequate moisture levels. However, reduce watering during dormancy in fall and winter to prevent the bulbs from rotting, as the plant requires less water at this time. Stand the pot on a saucer filled with water during very dry spells to maintain humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crinum americanum prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. For best results, provide the plant with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to protect the leaves from scorching. If you’re growing the plant indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. If outdoor light levels are low, consider supplementing with grow lights to ensure it gets enough light. Adequate light is crucial for healthy leaves and robust flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crinum americanum involves removing dead or yellowing leaves to maintain tidiness and promote better airflow. This can be done throughout the growing season as needed. After the plant blooms, you may also want to remove spent flower stalks by cutting them off at the base. This step not only keeps the plant looking neat but can also encourage the plant to put energy into bulb growth rather than seed production. Overall, Crinum americanum requires minimal pruning, so avoid over-pruning to allow it to develop naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Southern Swamp Crinum","description":"Crinum americanum is an aquatic angiosperm native to North America from Texas to South Carolina, as well as Mexico, Cuba, Jamaica and the Cayman Islands. Common names for this species include Florida swamp-lily, string lily, and southern swamp crinum. The species grows in small groups in still water habitats.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Southern Swamp Crinum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Crinum americanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist","Rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regularly checking for and removing any debris collected around the plant can also help prevent fungal issues and promote good air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"little brown jug","description":"Hexastylis arifolia, or the little brown jug, is a perennial wildflower in the family Aristolochiaceae found in the southeastern United States, from Louisiana to Virginia, inland as far as Kentucky. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14949,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sedum ternatum, or woodland stonecrop, prefers moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant once established, but for optimal growth, the soil should be kept slightly moist. Water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry, and ensure that it is not left soggy, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. During the growing season, regular watering helps maintain lush foliage, while in the winter months, reduce the frequency as the plant enters dormancy. Always water at the base to avoid wetting the foliage, which can lead to fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sedum ternatum thrives in partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for shaded garden areas. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates, excessive hot afternoon sun can scorch its leaves. Throughout the growing season, you can pinch back the tips in late spring or early summer to encourage bushier growth. Deadheading spent flowers can extend the blooming period. After the first frost in the fall, the plants can be cut back again to maintain a tidy appearance and prepare for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"New England aster","description":"Symphyotrichum novae-angliae (formerly Aster novae-angliae), the New England aster, hairy Michaelmas-daisy, or Michaelmas daisy, is a species of flowering plant in the family Asteraceae. It is a perennial, herbaceous plant native to eastern North America, and has been introduced to Europe. The seeds and nectar of this fall-flowering species are important to a wide variety of animals. Numerous cultivars have been developed and the species is a popular garden plant, especially in Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["New England aster"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum novae-angliae"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14651,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhodiola rhodantha prefers moderate watering, as it is adapted to growing in well-drained, rocky soils often found in alpine regions. Allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot, which can occur if the roots are kept too wet. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water moderately to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant's growth slows down and it requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhodiola rhodantha thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, provide the plant with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some shaded environments, too much shade may reduce flowering and cause leggier growth. In especially hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade can help protect the plant from the intense midday sun, which can scorch the leaves or cause stress during extreme heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Rhodiola rhodantha is generally minimal, as it maintains a tidy growth habit on its own. However, you can remove any dead or damaged leaves or flower stems to tidy the appearance and encourage new growth. This is best done in early spring before the plant begins its active growth cycle. Deadheading spent flowers can also promote a longer flowering period, and removing dried stalks at season's end will help prepare the plant for overwintering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Queen's Crown","description":"Rhodiola rhodantha, common name redpod stonecrop or queen's crown, is a perennial flowering plant in the family Crassulaceae....","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Queen's Crown"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Rhodiola rhodantha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15443,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Passiflora tripartita, commonly known as the banana passionfruit, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It is essential not to let the plant completely dry out between waterings. Depending on the climate, watering is usually necessary two to three times a week, especially in hot weather. However, it is crucial to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. In cooler months, the watering frequency should be reduced, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Regularly check the plant's soil moisture level to ensure it is adequate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Passiflora tripartita thrives in full sun to partial shade, needing at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering and fruiting. It can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but too little light may reduce its blooming potential. Ideal conditions would have the plant in morning sun and afternoon shade if the sun is particularly intense. If grown indoors or in a greenhouse, ensure it is positioned where it can receive plenty of bright, indirect light. Adjust its position if blooming decreases, indicating the need for more sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Passiflora tripartita is best done in the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This helps control the plant's size and encourages healthy, vigorous growth. Cut back any dead or weak stems to the base. It's also important to remove any crossing branches which may lead to tangled growth. Maintaining a tidy structure allows more light and air to reach through to the center of the plant, reducing the risk of disease. Continuous checking and light pruning throughout the growing season will help manage its growth and promote flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"banana passionfruit","description":"Banana passionfruit is the fruit of several plants in the genus Passiflora, and is therefore related to the passion fruit. They look somewhat like a straight, small banana with rounded ends. It was given this name in New Zealand, where passionfruit are also prevalent. In Hawaii, it is called banana poka. In its Latin American homeland, it is known as curuba, curuba de Castilla, or curuba sabanera blanca (Colombia); taxo, tacso, tagso, tauso (Ecuador); parcha, taxo...","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["banana passionfruit"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Passiflora tripartita"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15644,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Veronicastrum virginicum, also known as Culver's root, prefers consistently moist soil, particularly during its growing period in spring and summer. It is important to water this plant regularly, especially during dry spells, to ensure that the soil remains damp but well-drained. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this can lead to stress and stunt the plant's growth. During the winter months, you can reduce watering, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings, as the plant enters a period of dormancy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Veronicastrum virginicum thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. However, it can tolerate partial shade, though flowering might be slightly less prolific. If growing in a hotter climate, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive midday heat and reduce water loss due to evaporation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Veronicastrum virginicum should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the previous year’s stems to just above ground level. This encourages vigorous new growth and ensures the plant maintains a tidy appearance. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers during the growing season can help extend the blooming period and keep the plant looking fresh. Be sure to remove any damaged or diseased stems throughout the growing season to maintain plant health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Culver's root","description":"Veronicastrum virginicum, or Culver's root, is a species of flowering plant in the plantain family, native to the eastern United States and south-eastern Canada. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14157,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Iris virginica, commonly known as Virginia iris or Southern blue flag, prefers consistently moist to wet soil conditions. It thrives in environments that mimic its natural marshy habitats, so regular watering is essential, especially during dry spells. Ensure the soil never dries out completely between waterings, aiming to keep it consistently moist. While it can tolerate temporarily flooded conditions, avoid letting the plant sit in stagnant water for prolonged periods to prevent root rot. Adjust watering frequency based on humidity and temperature, reducing slightly during cooler months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris virginica thrives best in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote optimal growth and flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and weaker plant growth. In areas with particularly intense afternoon sun, some light shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. When planting, choose a location that allows for ample morning sunlight while protecting the plant from overly harsh afternoon rays if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Iris virginica involves removing spent flowers and dead foliage to promote new growth and maintain plant health. After the blooming season, cut back the flower stalks to just above the base to prevent seed formation and encourage further blooming. Trim away any withered or yellowing leaves, cutting them back to the ground to minimize disease risk and improve the plant's appearance. In late winter to early spring, a thorough cleaning can be conducted, removing any remaining dead or damaged foliage before new growth begins."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"southern blue flag","description":"Iris virginica, with the common name Virginia iris, is a perennial species of flowering plant, native to eastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["southern blue flag"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Rhizome Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Iris virginica"],"soil":["Wet","Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14552,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drosera spatulata, commonly known as the spoon-leaf sundew, thrives in consistently moist conditions. It's important to water this plant regularly, ideally using the tray method. This involves placing the pot in a shallow tray filled with distilled or rainwater, ensuring that the medium is saturated without becoming waterlogged. Tap water should be avoided due to mineral build-up. The pot must have drainage holes to prevent root rot. During colder months, reduce the water slightly but maintain enough moisture to prevent the substrate from drying out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drosera spatulata requires bright, indirect sunlight to thrive. Ideally, it should receive at least four to six hours of filtered sunlight per day, which encourages maximum dew production on its leaves. Direct sunlight may cause leaf burn, particularly during the hottest part of the day, so consider placing the plant near an east or north-facing window where it will receive gentle morning light. If growing under artificial lighting, use fluorescent lights placed a few inches above the plant. Ensure it receives 12 to 16 hours of light daily to simulate its natural growing conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Drosera spatulata is minimal but can help maintain its health and appearance. Remove dead or dying leaves by carefully trimming them with sterilized scissors or tweezers to prevent mold growth and maintain airflow. Trim any flower stalks after blooming to redirect energy back into leaf production. Be gentle to avoid disturbing the plant's roots and sticky, dew-covered leaves. Regularly inspect for any signs of disease or pests, and promptly remove affected areas to prevent spread. No major pruning or shaping is necessary for this low-maintenance carnivorous plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rosy Sundew","description":"Drosera spatulata, the spoon-leaved sundew, is a variable, rosette-forming sundew with spoon-shaped leaves. The specific epithet is Latin for \"spatula shaped,\" a reference to the form of the leaves. This sundew has a large range and occurs naturally throughout Southeast Asia, in southern China and Japan, Micronesia, New Guinea through to the eastern territories of Australia and Tasmania and New Zealand. Variants are often known by the localities in which they are found. Water newly planted pines regularly during their first growing season to establish a strong root system. Once established, the mugo pine should only be watered during prolonged dry periods, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot and other diseases. It's important to ensure the soil dries out between waterings. Deep, infrequent watering encourages deep root growth, enhancing drought resistance. In areas with natural rainfall, supplemental watering may not be necessary once the plant is established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus mugo thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure ensures the best growth and encourages the plant's naturally dense form. In shaded areas, it may become more open and less compact. If planted in a garden setting, consider siting it on the south or west side of the landscape for maximum sunlight exposure throughout the day. Adequate light is essential for its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus mugo should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth emerges, to maintain its shape and encourage density.
