Avoid cutting into the older, bare wood, as this can lead to bare patches. Regular maintenance will help maintain a compact and attractive form. It's also important to sterilize pruning tools before use to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mountain pine","description":"Pinus mugo, known as creeping pine, dwarf mountainpine, mugo pine, mountain pine, scrub mountain pine or Swiss mountain pine, is a species of conifer, native to high elevation habitats from southwestern to Central Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central Europe","Southern Europe"],"other_name":["mountain pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pine sawfly","Aphids","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus mugo"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. In the dormant months (fall and winter), reduce watering frequency as the plant's water needs decrease. Always ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent standing water, which is detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asparagus densiflorus thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. While it can tolerate some direct sun, especially in the morning or late afternoon, too much direct light, particularly during the harsh midday hours, can scorch the leaves. In lower light conditions, though this plant can adapt, it may become less dense and more leggy, indicating it needs more light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asparagus densiflorus is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging new growth. Trim back any brown or yellowing stems, as these are often indicators of old or damaged foliage. Use clean, sharp scissors to cut these stems back to the base. Regular pruning can also prevent the plant from becoming too leggy or overgrown. Additionally, removing old stems can help to rejuvenate the plant and promote more bushy growth. Prune during the growing season when the plant is actively producing new shoots for the best results."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sprenger's Asparagus","description":"Asparagus densiflorus (asparagus fern, plume asparagus, foxtail fern) is an evergreen perennial plant, closely related to the vegetable asparagus, and native to southern Africa from Mozambique to South Africa. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15150,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Moraea collina, commonly known as the 'Cape Tulip,' prefers moderate watering. It requires somewhat less water during its dormant period in the summer. During its growth period in the winter and spring, ensure that the soil remains consistently moist but not soaked. Water this plant carefully, allowing the topsoil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Always ensure good drainage by using pots with holes to avoid standing water. As it's adapted to South African conditions, more frequent watering might be necessary in drier climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Moraea collina thrives in full sunlight, similar to its native South African habitat. For optimal growth, place this plant in a location where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. If grown indoors, position it near a south-facing window to maximize light exposure. However, in extremely hot conditions, some afternoon shade can prevent potential leaf scorch. Lack of adequate sunlight can lead to poor flowering and leggy growth, so it's important to provide bright, direct light whenever possible."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Moraea collina is minimal, mainly involving the removal of spent blooms and dead foliage to promote new growth and to maintain a tidy appearance. This should be done carefully and regularly throughout the growing season. Remove dead or yellowing leaves by cutting them close to the base without damaging the healthy parts of the plant. After the flowering season, allow the foliage to die back naturally, as the leaves will continue to photosynthesize, strengthening the corm for the next season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cape Tulip","description":"Moraea collina is a species of the genus Moraea, in the family Iridaceae. It was formerly known as Homeria collina.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cape Tulip"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Moraea collina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from scorching. Regardless, ensure it gets ample morning sunlight to support its blooming cycle and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hymenocallis liriosme is relatively straightforward and involves removing spent flowers and any yellowing or dead foliage to encourage healthy new growth. Additionally, in late winter or early spring, you can trim back any dead or damaged leaves to make way for new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"spring spiderlily","description":"Hymenocallis liriosme is a North American bulb-forming herb native to Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Mississippi and Alabama.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["spring spiderlily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Hymenocallis liriosme"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14158,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Anemone hupehensis, commonly known as Japanese anemone, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. Water them regularly, especially during prolonged dry periods, to maintain even moisture without making the soil waterlogged. The goal is to keep the soil lightly moist at all times. During periods of heavy rainfall, ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature. Adjust watering frequency based on your climate, more in hot summers, and less in cooler periods, but never let the soil fully dry out between watering cycles."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anemone hupehensis thrives in partial shade to full sun environments. Ideally, they should receive morning sunlight and afternoon shade to protect them from the hot midday sun. In cooler climates, they can tolerate more direct sunlight, while in hotter areas, more shade is beneficial to prevent wilting and scorching. These plants are quite adaptable but may not flower well in deep shade. Too much shade can lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. Test different locations in your garden to find the right balance for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anemone hupehensis involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage further blooming and maintain a tidy appearance. After the flowering season, you can cut back the plant to ground level to tidy up your garden and prepare it for winter. This also helps prevent pests and diseases. In spring, remove any dead or damaged foliage to make way for new growth. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season as this can stress the plant. Regular light pruning ensures healthy growth and vibrant blooms the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hubei Anemone","description":"Anemone hupehensis, Anemone hupehensis var. japonica, and Anemone × hybrida (commonly known as the Chinese anemone or Japanese anemone, thimbleweed, or windflower) are species of flowering herbaceous perennials in the Ranunculaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China"],"other_name":["Hubei Anemone"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Root rot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Anemone hupehensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Fertile"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14353,"attracts":["Birds","Squirrels"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus stellata, commonly known as post oak, is a drought-tolerant tree that requires minimal watering once it is established. During its first growing season, it should be watered regularly to help it establish a strong root system, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. After establishment, supplemental watering is generally unnecessary unless there are prolonged periods of drought. In such cases, deep watering once every few weeks can help. It’s important to avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot and other water-related issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus stellata thrives in full sun, which means it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and health. This oak species is well-adapted to sunny environments and can tolerate hot, sunny conditions once established. It can also survive in partial shade, but this might lead to a less dense foliage and reduced overall vigor. Planting it in a location where it can soak in ample sunlight will help it develop a strong structure and enhance its resistance to pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus stellata should be done primarily to remove dead, diseased, or broken branches. Ideally, this should be done during the late winter or early spring while the tree is still dormant to reduce stress and prevent sap loss. Light pruning can also help shape young trees and enhance structural strength. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this can lead to significant water loss and stress. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the tree and promote healthy healing where cuts are made."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"post oak","description":"Quercus stellata, the post oak or iron oak, is a North American species of oak in the white oak section. It is a slow-growing oak that lives in dry, poor soils, and is resistant to rot, fire, and drought. Interbreeding occurs among white oaks, thus many hybrid species combinations occur.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["post oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Galls","Oak leaf blister","Armillaria root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus stellata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14751,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Staphylea trifolia, commonly known as American bladdernut, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season in the spring and early summer. However, it's crucial to ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent water-logged conditions, which can lead to root rot. In cooler, rainy autumns or winters, watering can be reduced significantly, only providing extra moisture during particularly dry spells."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"American bladdernut thrives in part to full shade, making it an excellent choice for woodland gardens. While it can tolerate partial sunlight, direct exposure to intense afternoon sun in hotter climates may cause leaf scorch. Ideally, it should receive morning sunlight with afternoon shade or be situated under tall trees where light is dappled. This plant is adaptable and can tolerate deeper shade, but flowering might be reduced in such conditions. A balance of light and shade ensures optimal growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Staphylea trifolia should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This shrub generally requires minimal pruning, only to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased wood. It's beneficial to thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation, which helps to prevent fungal diseases. If reducing size is necessary, prune back the previous year's growth by about one-third. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can diminish the plant's ability to flower in the upcoming season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American bladdernut","description":"Staphylea trifolia, the American bladdernut, is native to eastern North America, from southern Ontario and southwestern Quebec west to Nebraska and Arkansas, and south to Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["American bladdernut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Staphylea trifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15545,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus ayacahuite, commonly known as the Mexican White Pine, prefers well-drained soils and does not require frequent watering once established. During its initial growth stage, it’s important to maintain consistent moisture in the soil, watering deeply and infrequently to encourage deep root growth. Typically, watering once a week is sufficient, but the frequency may need adjustment based on climate conditions and soil type. Be cautious of overwatering, as it can lead to root rot. In drier climates, more regular watering may be necessary, especially during prolonged dry periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus ayacahuite thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. It can tolerate partial shade, but sufficient sunlight is crucial for its health and development. When planting, choose a site with good exposure to sunlight. If growing in a region with intense afternoon sun, some light afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the foliage from getting scorched. Make sure the tree has enough space to receive sunlight evenly as it grows, preventing lopsided growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus ayacahuite should be minimal and is usually done to remove dead or diseased branches. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Avoid heavy pruning that may cause stress to the tree. Reduced watering is required in cooler months as the plant goes partially dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arabis alpina prefers full sun to light shade conditions. It flourishes in locations with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. Full sun promotes more robust flowering and maintains its compact growth. However, it can tolerate light shading, especially in hotter climates, where some afternoon shade can prevent leaf burn. If grown in too much shade, the plant might become leggy and produce fewer flowers. This process not only tidies the plant but can also promote a second, though less vigorous, bloom. General maintenance pruning may also involve removing any dead or damaged foliage throughout the year. Overgrown plants can be reduced in size, but it is best to do this after flowering to avoid cutting away potential blooms."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Alpine Rock-cress","description":"Arabis alpina, the Alpine rock-cress, is a flowering plant in the family Brassicaceae, native to mountainous areas of Europe, North and East Africa, Central and Eastern Asia and parts of North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14159,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Castilleja occidentalis, commonly known as Western Indian Paintbrush, prefers well-drained soil with a relatively low watering requirement. This plant is adapted to dry, alpine, or subalpine habitats and does not tolerate wet or waterlogged conditions. Watering should be infrequent, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other fungal issues. During the active growing season, a deep watering every 1-2 weeks should be sufficient, depending on the local climate and soil conditions. Reduce watering significantly during the dormant season in fall and winter."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Castilleja occidentalis thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce vibrant flowers and sustain its hemiparasitic lifestyle, in which it partly relies on the roots of other plants. In warmer climates, providing some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent heat stress. However, in colder or wind-exposed areas, full sun exposure is ideal to ensure adequate growth and flowering. Position the plant where it can bask in ample sunlight but also benefit from some shelter in particularly harsh conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Castilleja occidentalis is minimal, focusing more on deadheading and removing spent flowers to encourage further blooming and to prevent excess self-seeding if desired. This can help maintain a tidier appearance and allocation of nutrients to healthier parts of the plant. Since the plant is hemiparasitic, relying partly on other plants for nutrients, care should be taken when trimming to not overly disrupt its host relationship. In early spring or late winter, remove any dead or damaged stems to promote new growth. Avoid hard pruning as this can harm the plant's development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Indian Paintbrush","description":"Castilleja occidentalis is a member of the genus Castilleja (paintbrush), commonly referred to as western Indian paintbrush. During hot or dry conditions, increase watering frequency to prevent the soil from drying out completely. Providing adequate shade helps maintain soil moisture, crucial for the plant’s health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viola striata is minimal but necessary to maintain its health and appearance. As the growing season ends, trim back any damaged or yellowing leaves to improve air circulation around the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14354,"attracts":["Birds","Squirrels"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus michauxii, or swamp chestnut oak, prefers moist environments typical of its native habitats. It does best with soil that is consistently moist but not waterlogged. During dry periods, regular watering will help maintain its health, especially for young trees still establishing roots. Ensure water deeply reaches the root system, mimicking the tree's natural floodplain conditions. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. In general, more established trees are drought-tolerant, but supplemental watering during prolonged dry spells is beneficial for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus michauxii thrives in full sun, where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. While it is also able to tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and acorn production are achieved with more sunlight. Placing the tree in a location with good sunlight exposure is ideal, as this mimics the tree's natural environment within floodplains and bottomlands. When grown in shaded areas, the tree may exhibit slower growth and become more susceptible to pests and diseases. Providing ample sunlight ensures robust development and a healthy canopy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Quercus michauxii should focus on maintaining a strong structure and removing any dead, diseased, or crossing branches. Prune the tree during its dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This minimizes stress and potential pest or disease intrusion. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can reduce the tree's vigor. Remove suckers and water sprouts routinely to direct energy to the main canopy. Regularly check for deadwood and damaged limbs, especially after storms, to keep the tree healthy and aesthetically pleasing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"swamp chestnut oak","description":"Quercus michauxii, the swamp chestnut oak, is a species of oak in the white oak section Quercus section Quercus in the beech family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14752,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phlox drummondii, commonly known as annual phlox, requires regular watering to thrive, especially during dry spells. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions. Be cautious during periods of high humidity or cooler temperatures, as the plant may require less frequent watering. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox drummondii thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to produce vibrant blooms and healthy foliage. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. In regions with intense summer heat, light afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. Place it in a well-lit location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day to ensure optimal growth and blooming potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox drummondii is essential for promoting bushier growth and prolonging blooming periods. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to encourage more blossoms and prevent seed formation. Additionally, trim back any leggy or weak growth to maintain a compact shape. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. In late summer or after flowering has finished, cut the plant back by about one-third to rejuvenate it and prepare it for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Drummond's phlox","description":"Phlox drummondii (commonly annual phlox or Drummond's phlox) is a flowering plant in the genus Phlox of the family Polemoniaceae. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, which typically means watering deeply every 10 to 14 days depending on humidity and climate conditions. Be cautious not to overwater, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. It's best to water early in the day, so the soil has time to dry before evening. Monitor the plant for signs of too much or too little light, such as scorched leaves or leggy growth, and adjust its location accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Trichostema dichotomum helps to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems, cutting back to healthy wood. You can also trim back any excessively long or leggy stems to promote a more compact form, but avoid cutting more than a third of the plant at once. Deadheading spent flowers can prolong blooming and improve appearance, but it's not necessary for the plant's overall health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Blue Curls","description":"Trichostema dichotomum, with the common name forked bluecurls, is a plant in the mint family (Lamiaceae), that is native to eastern North America....","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Blue Curls"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Trichostema dichotomum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts just above a leaf node to encourage new growth from that point."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cape Fig","description":"Ficus sur, with the common names Cape fig and broom cluster fig, is a widespread Afrotropical species of cauliflorous fig.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Africa"],"other_name":["Cape Fig"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root knot nematodes","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ficus sur"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14452,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oclemena acuminata, commonly known as whorled wood aster, prefers consistently moist soils, so it is important to water it regularly. However, it should never be waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. The key is to maintain an evenly damp environment, especially during dry spells. Mulching can help keep the soil moist and reduce the need for frequent watering. During periods of active growth, monitor the soil moisture closely, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Avoid letting the plant dry out completely, especially under hot and sunny conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oclemena acuminata prefers partial to full shade conditions, making it an ideal plant for woodland gardens or areas with dappled sunlight. However, leaving some seed heads can provide food for birds and add winter interest to the garden. In late fall or early winter, cut back the plant's foliage to a few inches above the ground. In natural settings, these plants often rely on rain, so in a garden environment, mimic these conditions by checking the soil moisture level regularly and adjusting your watering frequency accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Claytonia virginica prefers partial to full shade conditions, as it naturally grows in woodland areas under the canopy of deciduous trees. After the flowering period, it's advisable to remove dead blossoms to prevent seed formation unless you want the plant to self-seed. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15638,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tillandsia ionantha is an air plant, which means it absorbs moisture and nutrients through its leaves rather than roots in soil. To properly water this plant, mist it thoroughly 2 to 3 times a week, ensuring all the leaves are moistened. Alternatively, you can soak the entire plant in water for about 20-30 minutes once a week, allowing it to dry completely in a well-ventilated area afterward. Be cautious of water pooling in the center of the plant to prevent rot, especially in humid environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tillandsia ionantha thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight, especially during the intense midday hours, can damage the leaves by causing them to scorch. If grown indoors, place the plant near a window with filtered light, like a north or east-facing window. Outdoor positioning should ensure that the plant is protected by partial shade. In conditions where sufficient natural light isn't available, artificial fluorescent lighting can substitute, but it's crucial to avoid excess or insufficient light exposure to maintain its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is minimal for Tillandsia ionantha. Since air plants do not grow roots like typical plants, most attention to pruning involves removing dried or dead leaves, which can occur at the plant's base or tips. Use sanitized scissors to remove these parts, ensuring a clean cut. These plants will naturally propagate by producing offsets or 'pups' after blooming. Once pups are a third the size of the parent, they can be gently pulled apart to promote airflow and avoid crowding, enhancing their shape and health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Blushing Bride Airplant","description":"Tillandsia ionantha, the sky plant, is a species in the genus Tillandsia. This species is native to Central America and Mexico. It is also reportedly naturalized in Broward County, Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Blushing Bride Airplant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Offset Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Tillandsia ionantha"],"soil":["None required as plant doesn't need soil"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If planted in too much shade, the plant may grow but will produce fewer flowers, so balance is key based on your local climate and garden exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Clematis columbiana should be done to maintain the plant's shape and encourage healthy growth. As it flowers on the previous year's growth, prune lightly each spring to remove any dead or weak stems, cutting back to healthy buds. Avoid heavy pruning which could reduce flowering. After blooming, a light trim can help control the size and shape of the plant. Make sure to use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent disease spread. Regularly check and remove any dead or diseased parts throughout the season to keep the vine healthy and vigorous."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"blue clematis","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["blue clematis"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Clematis columbiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy, watering just enough to keep the roots from drying out completely. Ideally, this plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to promote strong growth and flowering. In hotter climates, it can benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent overheating and excess moisture loss. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade can result in leggy growth and fewer flowers. Thus, for optimal blooming, place it in a location where it receives morning sun and some protection from the harsh afternoon sun, especially in warmer zones."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Scutellaria incana should be done to encourage bushier growth and remove any dead or diseased stems. Trim back the plant in early spring before new growth begins, cutting back old stems to about 6 inches from the base. This encourages healthy new growth and flowering. After the flowering period ends, you may deadhead spent blooms to prevent self-seeding, though the interesting seed pods can also be left for winter interest. Maintain a neat appearance by removing any damaged stems throughout the growing season. Minimal pruning is usually sufficient for this hardy perennial."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Downy Skullcap","description":"Scutellaria incana, the hoary skullcap or downy skullcap, is a flowering plant in the family Lamiaceae and is native to North America. Allow the leaves to remain, as they help the plant store energy for the next season. Once the leaves turn yellow and die back naturally, they can be removed gently. Avoid cutting off leaves too early or damaging the base as this can be detrimental to the plant’s overall health and ability to regenerate for the next growing cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cowslip Orchid","description":"Caladenia flava, commonly known as cowslip orchid, is a species of orchid endemic to the south-west of Western Australia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14744,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cardamine douglassii prefers consistently moist soil, particularly during its growing season in spring. It thrives in areas that mimic its natural habitats like woodland edges or stream banks. Ensure the soil never completely dries out, as this can stress the plant and inhibit its growth. Watering should be done regularly but avoid waterlogging, as overly saturated soil may cause root rot. Mulching can help retain moisture in the soil, especially during warmer months or in drier climates. Adjust watering frequency based on rainfall and soil condition, keeping the moisture steady and adequate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cardamine douglassii is well-suited to partial to full shade environments since it naturally grows in woodland areas. It can handle some morning sun but should be protected from harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch its leaves. If grown in a garden, consider placing this plant under larger shrubs or trees to provide filtered sunlight, recreating the dappled sunlight of its natural habitat. If you notice the plant's leaves are paling or developing brown edges, it might be receiving too much sun and may need to be moved to a shadier location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cardamine douglassii is generally minimal as it is a low-maintenance plant. Remove dead or yellowing leaves to maintain a tidy appearance and to encourage new growth. After the flowering period, you might choose to deadhead spent flowers to prevent self-seeding if they're becoming too invasive or to prolong the blooming period slightly. In late fall, cut back the foliage if it becomes unsightly, or leave it to provide winter interest and protection for the plant. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp tools to avoid tearing and damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Purple Cress","description":"Cardamine douglassii (known by the common names limestone bittercress and purple cress) is a perennial forb native to the eastern and central United States as well as the province of Ontario in Canada, that produces white to pink or purple flowers in early spring.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Purple Cress"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Cardamine douglassii"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16027,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Antennaria parvifolia, commonly known as small-leaf pussytoes, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. During the growing season, water it lightly and allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil. In winter, reduce watering almost entirely, as the plant enters dormancy and requires very little moisture. For container-grown plants, be particularly careful not to let water accumulate in the saucer."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Antennaria parvifolia thrives best in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to support healthy foliage and vibrant flowering. In hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent heat stress. Ensure the plant is not in a location with too much shade, as this can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window that receives ample sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Antennaria parvifolia is typically minimal. You should remove any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth and maintain its appearance. After the flowering season, deadhead faded blooms to encourage a tidy look and possibly a second bloom. In late fall or early winter, you can cut back the plant to tidy up the appearance and prepare it for the next growing season. This also helps prevent mildew and encourages more robust growth in the spring. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"small-leaf pussytoes","description":"Antennaria parvifolia is a North American species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common names Nuttall's pussytoes and small-leaf pussytoes (not to be confused with littleleaf pussytoes). It is native to central and western North America, where it is widespread in Canada, the United States, and northern Mexico from British Columbia east to Ontario and south to California, Chihuahua, and Nuevo León. It has not been observed in California since 1987.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["small-leaf pussytoes"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Antennaria parvifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, keep the soil evenly moist, particularly in dry periods or if the plant is grown in a container. In winter, reduce watering but do not let the soil dry out completely. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent excessive heat stress, which can damage the plant. Ensure that it receives at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. However, be cautious of extremely high temperatures and adjust its light exposure accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bistorta vivipara is mostly about deadheading to encourage more blooms and tidying up the plant. Remove withered or spent flowers to prevent the plant from self-seeding and to encourage further flowering. Additionally, cut back any dead or damaged stems in early spring before new growth begins. This helps to maintain the plant’s appearance and health. Avoid cutting back too harshly, as the plant requires its leaves for photosynthesis during the summer months."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"alpine bistort","description":"Persicaria vivipara is a perennial herbaceous flowering plant in the knotweed and buckwheat family Polygonaceae, commonly known as alpine bistort. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14546,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Woodsia obtusa, commonly known as the blunt-lobed Woodsia or rusty Woodsia, prefers consistently moist soil but can tolerate occasional dry periods. It's essential to ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the roots. Water this fern regularly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. While more drought-tolerant than many ferns, during especially dry spells or in higher temperatures, increase the frequency slightly to maintain adequate moisture levels in the soil. Using rainwater or dechlorinated water is often beneficial for preventing salt build-up in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Woodsia obtusa thrives best in partial to full shade conditions. While it can tolerate brief periods of direct sunlight, excessive exposure can lead to leaf scorching. Ideally, provide it with dappled sunlight, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. In more northern climates, where the sunlight is less intense, it may tolerate morning sun, but protection from the harsh afternoon sun is crucial. Offering shade through trees or placing it in areas with indirect light will result in optimal growth and ensure the plant maintains vibrant, healthy fronds throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Woodsia obtusa is generally minimal but can be beneficial for aesthetics and plant health. Remove any dead or damaged fronds at the base to encourage healthy new growth and maintain the plant's appearance. This is usually done in late winter or early spring before the new growth starts. Remove fronds that have turned brown or are showing signs of diseases throughout the growing season. Regular pruning helps to reduce potential pest habitats and improves air circulation around the plant, promoting a healthier environment overall."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"blunt woodsia","description":"Woodsia obtusa, the bluntlobe cliff fern, is a common rock fern of Appalachia and eastern North America. It prefers a calcareous substrate, but also grows in neutral soils. During the growing season, it is advisable to water the plant moderately and allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. This plant is somewhat drought-tolerant, so it can withstand occasional periods of dryness. However, overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure proper drainage. In the winter months, when the plant is not in its active growth phase, watering frequency can be reduced. It's best to water in the early morning or late afternoon to minimize evaporation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chamaecrista nictitans thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, which will promote healthy growth and flowering. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent excessive drying and scorching of the leaves. If grown in partial shade, the plant might become leggier and produce fewer flowers. It's important to monitor the plant for signs of too little light, such as reduced flowering or weak, spindly growth, and adjust its location accordingly to enhance its light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chamaecrista nictitans is generally not necessary for the plant's health, but it can be done to maintain a desired shape or size, and to remove any dead or diseased stems. If you choose to prune, the best time is in the early spring before new growth starts. This allows the plant to recover quickly and encourages bushier growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts and be careful not to remove more than a third of the plant at one time to avoid stress. Pruning may also help control its somewhat sprawling growth habit."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"sensitive pea","description":"Chamaecrista nictitans, the sensitivie cassia, sensitive partridge pea, small partridge pea or wild sensitive plant, is a herbaceous species of legume widely distributed through the temperate and tropical Americas. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15439,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Berberis repens, commonly known as Creeping Barberry, prefers moderate watering. It requires consistent moisture but is also drought tolerant once established. During the plant's active growing season in spring and summer, it is important to water it regularly, ensuring that the soil is kept slightly moist but not waterlogged. In contrast, during the fall and winter, you can reduce the watering frequency as the plant's growth slows down, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it may lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Creeping Barberry thrives in a variety of sunlight conditions but ideally prefers partial shade. It can tolerate full sun, particularly in cooler climates, but in regions with intense, hot summers, providing some afternoon shade is beneficial to prevent leaf scorch and stress. If planted in a mostly shaded area, the plant might produce fewer flowers and berries, which are not critical from a foliage perspective. Therefore, a balance, such as dappled sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade, is optimal to keep this plant healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Berberis repens is not overly demanding, as this plant generally maintains a low-growing, spreading habit. Pruning should be done mainly to shape the plant or control its size, ideally after it has finished blooming in late spring or early summer. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and encourage healthy growth. Additionally, trimming back excessively long stems can help maintain a neat and tidy appearance. Avoid heavy pruning as the plant naturally produces a dense, attractive foliage cover."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"creeping mahonia","description":"Mahonia repens commonly known as creeping mahonia, creeping Oregon grape, creeping barberry, or prostrate barberry, is a species of Mahonia native to the Rocky Mountains and westward areas of North America, from British Columbia and Alberta in the north through Arizona and New Mexico, then into northwest Mexico by some reports. It is also found in many areas of California and the Great Basin region in Nevada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["creeping mahonia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Berberis repens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14446,"attracts":["Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Frangula caroliniana, also known as Carolina buckthorn, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, to maintain its natural habitat conditions. While it does tolerate some drought, prolonged dry periods can stress the plant. Ensure that the soil is not waterlogged; a good rule of thumb is to water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the first year post-planting, ensure it receives ample water to establish a robust root system, after which it may be more tolerant of infrequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carolina buckthorn thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide a location where the plant receives at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight daily. While it is versatile enough to tolerate some shade, full sun conditions will encourage more prolific flowering and fruiting. If growing in an area mostly shaded, ensure it is near enough to natural light to prevent it from becoming overly leggy, which can result in a weaker structure. Monitor its growth and adjust the lighting conditions if needed to ensure health and vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Frangula caroliniana, or Carolina buckthorn, minimal pruning is typically required. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins to shape the plant or remove dead and diseased branches. This is best done to maintain the desired size and shape or to remove congested growth inside the plant. Regular pruning can also promote a bushier habit and increase airflow through the plant, which helps reduce the likelihood of disease. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant and lead to reduced flowering and fruiting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina buckthorn","description":"Frangula caroliniana, commonly called the Carolina buckthorn, is a deciduous upright shrub or small tree native to the southeastern, south-central, and mid-western parts of the United States, from Texas east to Florida and north as far as Maryland, Ohio, Missouri, and Oklahoma. There is also an isolated population in the State of Nuevo León in northeastern Mexico. It is found in a wide variety of habitats, including barrens, forests, and limestone bluffs.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Carolina buckthorn"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Frangula caroliniana"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When cultivating this plant, it's important to mimic its natural conditions by watering sparingly. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, which can occur in overly moist conditions. During the growing season in spring and summer, water more regularly—approximately once every 7 to 10 days, depending on the ambient temperature and humidity. In the cooler months, reduce watering to once every two weeks or when the soil feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mimetes fimbriifolius thrives in environments that offer full sun exposure. If kept indoors or in cooler climates, ensure it has a place near a bright, south-facing window, supplemented with artificial grow lights if natural light is insufficient."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Mimetes fimbriifolius should be done sparingly to maintain a natural shape and encourage healthy growth. Ideally, prune in late winter or early spring before the onset of new growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant and inhibit flowering. Instead, focus on light maintenance and thinning of crowded areas to maintain the plant's aesthetic form. To encourage bushier growth, pinch out the tips of young shoots gently."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tree pagoda-bush","description":"Mimetes fimbriifolius, also called cowl pagoda or the fringed pagoda, is a species of plant in the family Proteaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14945,"attracts":["Pollinators","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Shepherdia rotundifolia, or roundleaf buffaloberry, is a drought-tolerant shrub that thrives in dry conditions. It requires minimal watering, making it an excellent choice for xeriscaping. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. In general, once established, it may only need watering during extended periods of drought, about once every two to four weeks depending on the climate. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is essential to ensure proper drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Shepherdia rotundifolia thrives in full sun and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. This plant is native to open, arid regions and is well-adapted to bright, sunny environments, making it ideal for gardens that receive plenty of sunlight. If planted in a shaded area, the shrub may exhibit reduced flowering and slower growth. In climates with intense sun exposure, ensure the plant is gradually introduced to full sun conditions to prevent leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Shepherdia rotundifolia should be done to maintain its shape, remove dead or diseased wood, and encourage healthier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make precise cuts, and focus on removing any branches that cross or are congested. Clip away any dead or damaged branches and thin out the interior to increase air circulation. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the plant and reduce berry production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Roundleaf buffaloberry","description":"Shepherdia rotundifolia, the roundleaf buffaloberry or silverleaf, is a 3-to-6-foot (1-to-2-meter) evergreen shrub in the oleaster family (Elaeagnaceae) that grows only in the Colorado Plateau (endemic) of the southwestern United States.:97 The common name comes from western settlers using the cooked berries in a sauce for eating cooked buffalo meat.:97","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Roundleaf buffaloberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Shepherdia rotundifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning in the fall, as the plant needs to conserve its energy for the upcoming dormant season. Regular pruning every year or two is typically sufficient."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eastern green violet","description":"Hybanthus concolor is a member of the Violaceae (violet) family and is commonly known as eastern green violet. Encourage a bushy shape by cutting back the remaining stems to a lower outward-facing bud."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common dogwood","description":"Cornus sanguinea, the common dogwood or bloody dogwood, is a species of dogwood native to most of Europe and western Asia, from England and central Scotland east to the Caspian Sea. Ensure the soil has excellent drainage to prevent waterlogging. If you are growing this pine in a container or as part of a landscape with limited rainfall, water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus pungens thrives in full sunlight, which is essential for its growth and development. While it can tolerate partial shade, prolonged lack of sunlight may result in diminished growth and reduced needle density, affecting the tree's overall appearance and vigor. Ensure that the site is not prone to excessive shade, especially during the main daylight hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pinus pungens should be done with care to maintain its health and natural form. Pruning is generally only needed to remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches. This can be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize any potential damage to the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Table Mountain pine","description":"Table Mountain pine, Pinus pungens, also called hickory pine, prickly pine, or mountain pine, is a small pine native to the Appalachian Mountains in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Table Mountain pine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus pungens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15541,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus serotina, commonly known as the pond pine, has specific watering needs. This tree prefers moist, well-drained soils and thrives in areas with consistent moisture, such as wetlands or areas prone to seasonal flooding. When cultivated in less naturally moist environments, it's important to ensure the soil remains slightly damp, particularly during dry periods. During the growing season, water deeply once a week, allowing the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. It's crucial not to overwater, as pond pines do not tolerate standing water around their roots for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus serotina grows best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to thrive. This sunlight exposure is essential for optimal growth, cone production, and overall health. In its natural habitat, the pond pine often grows in open, sunny areas such as wetlands, swamps, or flatwoods where competition for light is minimal. When planting in a garden or landscape, ensure it is situated in a location that receives ample sunlight. Partial shade can be tolerated, but diminished light can lead to slower growth and a less robust tree structure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus serotina should be done lightly and primarily for the removal of dead or damaged branches to maintain tree health and appearance. The preferred time for pruning is late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Avoid pruning in late summer or fall, as this can stimulate new growth that will not harden off before winter, making it susceptible to damage. Since this species naturally has an open, irregular crown, minimal pruning is needed. Maintaining the natural form is usually best, so only prune to alter the shape or size if absolutely necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pond pine","description":"Pinus serotina, the pond pine, marsh pine or pocosin pine, is a tree found along the Southeastern portion of the Atlantic coastal plain of the United States, from southern New Jersey south to Florida and west to southern Alabama. This pine often has a crooked growth pattern and an irregular top and grows up to 21 metres (69 ft) high, rarely to 29 metres (95 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["pond pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal pathogens"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus serotina"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16030,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Apium prostratum, commonly known as sea celery, prefers consistently moist soil but not waterlogged. It thrives with regular watering, particularly during dry spells or when grown in pots. To ensure optimal growth, water the plant deeply about once a week or when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Be cautious of overwatering, as soggy conditions can lead to root rot. In coastal areas or when grown near saltwater, it can tolerate some salt spray, but always aim to maintain soil moisture without waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Apium prostratum thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers a few hours of direct sunlight each day, ideally in the morning or late afternoon, which encourages healthy, robust growth. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf burn and conserve moisture. However, in cooler regions, maximizing sun exposure is beneficial for the plant's overall vitality. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window where it can receive ample natural light, but avoid direct, intense midday sun to prevent stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Apium prostratum should be done to encourage bushy growth and to maintain the plant's shape. Regularly harvesting leaves and stems for culinary use can serve as an effective form of pruning. Remove any dead, damaged, or yellowing foliage to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. For established plants, you can cut back the stems significantly in late winter or early spring to promote vigorous new growth. Avoid cutting back all the way to the ground, and ensure your tools are clean to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sea Celery","description":"Apium prostratum, commonly known as sea celery, is a variable herb native to coastal Australia and New Zealand. The leaves are variable, with toothed leaflets, and a celery like aroma. The tiny white flowers occur in clusters.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Sea Celery"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Apium prostratum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15146,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cylindropuntia fulgida, commonly known as the chain fruit cholla, requires minimal watering. This desert plant is adapted to arid environments and should be watered sparingly. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. Overwatering is a common mistake, so it's crucial to monitor soil moisture and only water during extended dry periods or when the plant is showing signs of thirst, such as shriveling. In winter, reduce watering even more, as the plant goes into dormancy and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cylindropuntia fulgida thrives in full sunlight, as it is native to desert environments. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to flourish, making it ideal for outdoor planting in sunny climates. If grown indoors, place it near a south- or west-facing window where it can receive the maximum possible light exposure. Insufficient sunlight can lead to poor growth and a less vibrant appearance. If necessary, rotate the plant periodically to ensure all sides receive equal light, promoting even growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cylindropuntia fulgida is generally minimal, focusing mainly on removing any dead or damaged branches to maintain the plant's appearance and health. Use thick gloves and protective tools to handle the plant safely, as it has sharp spines. Prune during the growing season, preferably in spring or early summer. Avoid excessive pruning as this may stress the plant. Simply cut away any unsightly parts or shape the plant according to space requirements, and always ensure your tools are clean to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chain-fruit Cholla","description":"Cylindropuntia fulgida, the jumping cholla, also known as the hanging chain cholla, is a cholla cactus native to Sonora and the Southwestern United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Chain-fruit Cholla"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cylindropuntia fulgida"],"soil":["Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid over-saturating the growing medium to prevent mold or other fungal competitors. Ensure good ventilation and moderate humidity conditions to mimic its natural ecosystem."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laetiporus gilbertsonii typically grows on trees and prefers shaded or partially shaded conditions in its natural habitat. While cultivating this fungus, replicate its natural growing conditions by providing indirect light or dappled shade. Direct sunlight is not necessary and can dry out the fungus or its substrate too quickly. Ensuring that this fungus is not exposed to harsh lighting conditions will help maintain the correct moisture levels and temperature balance essential for its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning does not typically apply to Laetiporus gilbertsonii in the same way it does for plants. However, if you are cultivating this fungus, it is important to regularly inspect the fruiting bodies for any signs of decay or mold and remove them to prevent spoilage and contamination. Harvest the fungus when it is young and tender for the best quality, as older specimens can become tough. Regularly clear dead or decaying mushrooms to maintain a healthy growing environment and discourage pests."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Hardwood Sulphur Shelf","description":"Laetiporus gilbertsonii is a species of polypore fungus in the family Fomitopsidaceae. It is found in western North America. It was one of three new Laetiporus species published in 2001, which were distinguished genetically from the common Laetiporus sulphureus; the others were L. conifericola and L. huroniensis. The type collection, made in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park in 1997, was found fruiting on a eucalyptus tree. It has also been collected in Oregon and Washington. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15742,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coix lacryma-jobi, commonly known as Job's Tears, prefers consistently moist soil. Water them regularly to maintain soil moisture, especially during the dry season. However, avoid waterlogging as this may cause root rot. Ensure the soil has good drainage. Deep watering once a week is usually sufficient, but frequency may increase during hotter months or if the plant shows signs of drying out. Pay attention to the leaves; if they start to wilt or become dry, it might be a sign to increase watering. Enhance moisture retention by applying a layer of mulch around the base of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coix lacryma-jobi thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, ensure the plant receives at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In tropical or subtropical regions, partial shade may be beneficial during the hottest part of the day to prevent scorching. Placing them in an area that receives morning sun and afternoon shade can be effective. While they are tolerant of various light conditions, insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced flowering and stunted growth. In indoor settings, place them near a bright window to simulate ideal conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coix lacryma-jobi is not essential, but occasional pruning can encourage healthy growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems and leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetics. Cutting back the plant in late winter or early spring will stimulate fresh growth. Be cautious not to over-prune; removing no more than one-third of the plant in any pruning session is ideal. Additionally, trimming spent flowers can prevent unwanted seeding and help the plant direct energy into growing new foliage and flowers, keeping it vigorous and tidy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Job's Tears","description":"Job's tears (US) or Job's-tears (UK), scientific name Coix lacryma-jobi, also known as adlay or adlay millet, is a tall grain-bearing perennial tropical plant of the family Poaceae (grass family). It is native to Southeast Asia but elsewhere is cultivated in gardens as an annual. It has been naturalized in the southern United States and the New World tropics. In its native environment it is grown in higher areas where rice and corn do not grow...","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Indian Subcontinent","Southeast Asia","Malay Peninsula","Taiwan","China"],"other_name":["Job's Tears"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Coix lacryma-jobi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the environment is damp but not waterlogged to mimic its natural habitat, often found in temperate woodlands. Mist the area with water regularly if natural rainfall is insufficient, particularly during dry periods. Avoid letting the substrate dry out completely, as this can inhibit growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fistulina hepatica thrives in conditions with partial shade to full shade, as it naturally grows on the trunks of oak and other broadleaf trees in woodland environments. Direct sunlight should be avoided if possible, as this fungus prefers the cooler, shaded conditions beneath the tree canopy. Providing dappled or filtered sunlight can simulate the natural conditions under which this fungus thrives. If growing indoors or in cultivated conditions, ensure it is placed in a location that does not receive strong, direct sunlight, particularly during the hottest parts of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Fistulina hepatica does not require traditional pruning like other plants or fungi, as it is a type of bracket fungus that grows on the sides of trees. However, removing old or decaying fruiting bodies can help manage aesthetics and reduce pests. Use a clean knife or scissors to cut the fruiting bodies off at the base. Ensuring proper airflow around the trunks or logs where it grows naturally can minimize unsightly spore accumulation. Overall, minimal intervention is needed unless for harvesting or aesthetic purposes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Beefsteak Polypore","description":"Fistulina hepatica (beefsteak fungus, also known as beefsteak polypore, ox tongue, or tongue mushroom) is an unusual bracket fungus classified in the Agaricales, that is commonly seen in Britain, but can be found in North America, Australia, North Africa, Southern Africa and the rest of Europe. As its name suggests, it looks remarkably similar to a slab of raw meat. It's important to ensure proper drainage as excessive water can lead to root rot. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, the plant may require more frequent watering. Reduce watering during the fall and winter months as the plant enters a period of rest. Monitor the soil moisture by checking the top inch of soil; if it feels dry to the touch, it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Meriania nobilis thrives best with bright, indirect sunlight. Ideally, it should be placed in a position where it receives several hours of diffused or dappled light per day. If grown indoors, it can be placed near an east or west-facing window. In areas with intense sunlight, providing some form of shading during peak sun hours can help prevent leaf burn. It is not suited for deep shade, which can stunt its growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Meriania nobilis involves removing dead or diseased branches to promote healthy growth and maintain its attractive shape. Pruning should ideally be done in the late winter or early spring before the plant starts its active growth phase. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, which helps prevent the spread of disease. Additionally, remove any crossing branches to improve airflow within the canopy. Controlling its height and encouraging bushier growth can also be achieved through regular tip pruning. Always assess the plant for any signs of stress following pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"motley meriania","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["motley meriania"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Meriania nobilis"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14845,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lathyrus vernus, or spring vetchling, requires consistent moisture to thrive, especially during its growing season. It prefers well-drained soil that is kept evenly moist but should not be waterlogged, as excess water can lead to root rot. Watering should be increased during dry spells to ensure the soil remains moist, but reduced during the plant's dormant period in the late summer and fall. It's a good practice to water deeply and less frequently to promote deeper root growth, rather than shallow, frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lathyrus vernus thrives best in partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for woodland gardens or shaded borders. While it can tolerate some morning sun, it's crucial to protect it from harsh afternoon sunlight as this can cause the leaves to scorch, especially in hotter climates. In regions with cooler summers, the plant may tolerate more sunlight, but it's generally best to provide dappled shade to mimic its natural woodland habitat. Too much shade, however, may reduce flowering, so find a balance that suits your specific environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lathyrus vernus is relatively simple and mostly involves removing dead or diseased stems to maintain the plant's health and appearance. After the plant has finished flowering, you can cut back the stems to encourage new growth and potentially a second bloom. Regularly removing faded flowers will also help prevent the plant from spreading uncontrollably by self-seeding. In late autumn, cutting back the plant to ground level helps clean it up for the winter and can encourage healthy new growth in the spring."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"spring vetch","description":"Lathyrus vernus (spring vetchling, spring pea, or spring vetch) is a species of flowering herbaceous perennial plant in the genus Lathyrus, native to forests of Europe and Siberia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15044,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Desmanthus illinoensis, commonly known as Illinois Bundleflower, is quite drought-tolerant once established. It prefers moderate watering. Water young plants regularly to establish a robust root system—about once a week if rainfall is inadequate. Mature plants should only need supplemental watering during prolonged dry spells. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent standing water, which this plant does not tolerate well. Addressing its natural habitat, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings mimics its native prairie and woodland edge environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Illinois Bundleflower thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day, which supports its rich blooming and robust growth. In regions with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching. It is adapted to open prairies and meadows, so a bright and sunny spot will closely mimic its natural habitat. If planted in partial shade, it may experience reduced vigor and fewer blooms. Therefore, choosing a location with ample exposure to sunlight will yield the best results for this plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Desmanthus illinoensis is generally minimal, focusing on maintaining shape and encouraging bushier growth. During very hot spells, a little afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gladiolus carinatus mainly involves removing spent flower stalks to promote energy conservation and bulb development. After the flowers fade, cut the flower stalk down to the base. This prevents the plant from expending energy on seed production. Remove any dead or diseased foliage promptly to maintain plant health. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14550,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hexastylis minor, commonly known as little heartleaf, prefers consistently moist soil, akin to its natural woodland habitat. Water it thoroughly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Ensure it is not left in standing water as it may lead to root rot. During hot, dry spells or in higher temperatures, you may need to water more frequently to maintain the necessary moisture levels. Reduce watering during the winter months when the plant enters its dormant phase. Always consider the environmental humidity, as this plant benefits from the moisture found in shaded, woodland environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hexastylis minor thrives in partial to full shade, reflecting its natural preference for sheltered, forested environments. It should be shielded from direct sunlight, which can scorch its leaves. Morning sunlight or dappled light throughout the day is ideal. If planted indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window to avoid harsh sun exposure. In outdoor gardens, it is well-suited to shaded understory settings beneath trees or shrubs, providing it with the cool, shaded conditions that resemble its native woodland habitat. Ensure it receives some light, as total darkness can impede growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Hexastylis minor is generally minimal, primarily to remove dead or decaying leaves to maintain plant health and appearance. This should be done in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant's rhizomes or stems. Avoid cutting healthy leaves as they are essential for the plant's photosynthesis process. Since the plant grows low and spreads across the ground, trimming is not typically needed for shaping but can be done to manage space if it becomes too expansive for its allocated area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"little heartleaf","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["little heartleaf"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Hexastylis minor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
