{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14948,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex bigelowii, commonly known as Bigelow's Sedge, generally thrives in moist environments. When cultivating this plant, ensure the soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged. Regular watering is essential, especially during dry periods, but be careful not to overwater as it can lead to root rot. Adjust watering frequency based on your local climate and soil type. In natural settings like alpine or tundra regions, it usually receives sufficient moisture from the environment, so if you're attempting to simulate these conditions in a garden, mimic the steady moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex bigelowii prefers habitats with full sun to partial shade. In its native tundra or alpine environments, it is accustomed to long daylight hours, so providing ample sunlight mimics its natural conditions. Ideally, place it in a spot where it can receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day. However, it can also tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates where intense afternoon sun might be too harsh. Adjust based on your climate; cooler areas could benefit from more sun exposure to support its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex bigelowii is minimal but can be beneficial to maintain its appearance and health. Remove dead or damaged blades or stems using clean shears to encourage new growth. This is ideally done in early spring before the growing season begins. If the plant becomes too dense or starts to overshadow its neighbors, thinning out some of the older growth can allow light and air to reach the center, promoting overall plant vigor. However, avoid over-pruning, as this sedge thrives best with a natural, slightly unkempt look."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bigelow's sedge","description":"Carex bigelowii is a species of sedge known by the common names Bigelow's sedge and stiff sedge. Reduce watering slightly during its dormant period in winter, but ensure the soil does not dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mercurialis perennis thrives best in partial to full shade, mimicking its native woodland habitat. It can tolerate dappled sunlight that filters through trees but should be protected from the harsh, direct sun, which may scorch its leaves. If grown in a garden setting, under the canopy of other taller plants or alongside a shaded north or east-facing wall will provide the optimal conditions. Outdoor cultivation in dense shade where light cannot reach can stunt its growth, so balanced light conditions are necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Mercurialis perennis is typically minimal since it is a low-growing perennial. You can deadhead spent flowers to prevent unwanted self-seeding or to keep the plant tidy. Regular monitoring for any dead or diseased growth and removing such parts promptly will also benefit the plant's health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dog's Mercury","description":"Mercurialis perennis, commonly known as dog's mercury, is a woodland plant found in much of Europe as well as in Algeria, Iran, Turkey, and the Caucasus, but almost absent from Ireland, Orkney and Shetland. A member of the spurge family (Euphorbiaceae), it is a herbaceous, downy perennial with erect stems bearing simple, serrate leaves. The dioecious inflorescences are green, bearing inconspicuous flowers in March and April. It characteristically forms dense, extensive carpets on the floor of...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Dog's Mercury"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Mercurialis perennis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15147,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lyonia lucida, commonly known as fetterbush, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. This plant thrives in swampy areas, so it can tolerate wetter conditions than many other shrubs. During the growing season, water regularly to maintain consistent moisture, especially in dry spells. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot. In container settings, check the topsoil to ensure it remains slightly damp, watering when it begins to dry out. Over the winter months, watering can be reduced as the plant enters dormancy, but do not allow it to dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lyonia lucida thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should get about four to six hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with very hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and stress. This adaptability allows it to grow well under the dappled sunlight of pine woods or the edges of forested areas. However, if planted in too much shade, its flowering might reduce. When situating the plant, consider the local climate and adjust sunlight exposure accordingly to ensure optimal growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lyonia lucida is often necessary to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or diseased branches with clean, sharp pruners. Thinning out crowded areas will improve air circulation within the plant. Additionally, you can trim back any particularly lengthy or unruly stems to promote a more compact and aesthetically pleasing form. Prune lightly to maintain its natural shape, as over-pruning can stress the plant and reduce its flowering potential."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fetterbush lyonia","description":"Lyonia lucida is a species of flowering plant in the heath family known by the common names fetterbush lyonia, hurrahbush, and staggerbush. Other plants may be called fetterbush. This broadleaved evergreen plant grows on the coastal plain of the southeastern United States from Virginia to Florida to Louisiana. It also occurs in Cuba.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["fetterbush lyonia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Lyonia lucida"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14351,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oxalis luteola prefers moderately moist soil, so ensure you maintain a regular watering schedule. Water the plant deeply once the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot, so it is important to have well-draining soil and a pot with drainage holes. During the dormant period, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out more between watering sessions. This plant benefits from increased humidity levels, so consider misting the leaves occasionally or placing the pot on a tray filled with pebbles and water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oxalis luteola thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Position the plant near a window where it can receive plenty of filtered light throughout the day. Direct sunlight, especially harsh afternoon rays, can scorch the leaves and should be avoided. If grown indoors, placing the plant near an east or north-facing window is preferable. In outdoor settings, providing some dappled shade during the hottest part of the day will help prevent leaf burn. The right balance of light will promote healthy growth, vibrant leaf colors, and overall plant vitality, ensuring the plant remains lush and attractive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oxalis luteola involves trimming back dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthier growth and maintain an attractive appearance. Use sterilized scissors or pruning shears to avoid the spread of disease. Regularly remove any yellowing or dead foliage to improve air circulation around the plant. In the fall, you may cut back the plant to just above the soil level after the leaves have died back naturally for winter dormancy. This encourages fresh growth when the plant enters its active growing season in spring. Minimal pruning keeps the plant tidy and promotes vigorous growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Golden Sorrel","description":"Oxalis luteola is an Oxalis species found in South Africa. It was first described in 1794.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Golden Sorrel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Oxalis luteola"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14155,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Verbesina alternifolia, commonly known as wingstem, thrives in moist to wet soil conditions. It is best to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during the growing season. However, it can tolerate occasional dry periods once established. Use mulching to help retain soil moisture and reduce watering frequency. Avoid waterlogging the soil, as overly saturated conditions can lead to root rot. In areas with regular rainfall, supplemental watering may not be necessary. Adjust your watering schedule based on local climate conditions and rainfall patterns to ensure optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Verbesina alternifolia prefers full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and abundant flowering, provide the plant with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate some shade, too much shade can result in leggy growth and fewer blossoms. In hotter climates, a bit of afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. Ensuring that the plant receives adequate sunlight will lead to a healthier plant structure and more vibrant flowers. Position it in an open space where it can get the necessary light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Verbesina alternifolia involves removing spent flowers to promote continued blooming and prevent indiscriminate self-seeding. This can be done by deadheading the plant periodically throughout the growing season. Once the flowering season is over, you can cut back the stems to a height of about 6-12 inches to tidy up the plant and encourage healthy growth in the following season. If the plant becomes overly dense, thinning out some of the growth will improve air circulation and reduce the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wingstem","description":"Verbesina alternifolia is a species of flowering plant in the Asteraceae family. Ensure that the plant isn’t sitting in waterlogged soil by allowing excess water to drain away. In the cooler months, reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy, only watering when the soil is almost completely dry. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it’s better to err on the side of underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leonotis nepetifolia thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate partial shade, but insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced blooming. In climates with intense sun and heat, the plant benefits from some afternoon shade to protect it from scorching. If growing indoors or in a pot, ensure it is placed near a south-facing window or a spot where it can receive ample bright light throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leonotis nepetifolia is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively and to promote further blooming. At the end of the growing season, or in early spring, prune back any dead or damaged stems to maintain a tidy appearance. This also helps in stimulating robust new growth during the growing season. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can weaken the plant and reduce its flowering potential."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"lion's ear","description":"Leonotis nepetifolia, (also known as klip dagga, Christmas candlestick, or lion's ear), is a species of plant in the genus Leonotis and the family Lamiaceae (mint). It is native to tropical Africa and southern India. It can also be found growing abundantly in much of Latin America and the West Indies. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14650,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhytidiadelphus triquetrus, commonly known as big shaggy moss or electrified cat's-tail moss, typically thrives in moist environments but does not tolerate waterlogged conditions. Ensure the moss is kept consistently moist, particularly during dry periods. Use distilled or rainwater if possible, as tap water can contain chemicals that might harm the moss. If grown indoors or in terrariums, misting the moss periodically can help maintain adequate moisture levels while avoiding water pooling, which may lead to rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhytidiadelphus triquetrus prefers dappled sunlight or partial shade, as direct sunlight can be too harsh and lead to desiccation. If grown indoors, place it near a window with filtered light or in an area that receives indirect sunlight to mimic its natural habitat underneath forest canopies. While this moss can adapt to lower light conditions, providing a few hours of bright, indirect light will support optimal growth and maintain its lush, green appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhytidiadelphus triquetrus is usually minimal, as this moss doesn't require regular trimming. However, if the moss looks unsightly or grows beyond its desired boundary, trim back any excessive growth with clean scissors to maintain its appearance. Remove any dead or decaying parts to promote healthy growth and prevent mold. Pruning is best done during the growing season as the moss is most vigorous and can recover more quickly from any cuttings taken."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Big Shaggy-moss","description":"Rhytidiadelphus triquetrus, the big shaggy-moss or rough goose neck moss, is species of moss in the family Hylocomiaceae. It is often the dominating moss species in moderately rich forest habitats in the boreal regions and the Pacific Northwest. Because of its fuzzy appearance and tail-like shape it is also called the 'electrified cat's tail moss'. Not to be confused with square goose-necked moss, Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Big Shaggy-moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Rhytidiadelphus triquetrus"],"soil":["Acidic","Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15542,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus teocote, being a pine species, prefers well-drained soil and may not require frequent watering once established. It's important to let the soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In the initial growing years, regular watering helps establish the tree, particularly during dry periods. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to fungal diseases and other issues. During winter, natural precipitation might suffice, but if it's a particularly dry season, occasional watering might be necessary. Monitor soil moisture and adjust the watering frequency according to environmental conditions and the tree's growth stage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus teocote thrives in full sunlight, where it receives direct light for most of the day. Ideally, it should get at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. This species can tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but optimal growth and health are found in sunnier locations. Ensuring that this pine receives adequate sunlight will promote robust growth and vibrant foliage. However, young seedlings might require some protection from intense midday sun to prevent damage until they are well established."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pinus teocote is generally minimal and primarily involves removing dead or diseased branches to maintain tree health. It's best to prune these pines during their dormant season, typically late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cutting should be clean to encourage proper healing and prevent disease. Avoid cutting the main leader as pines naturally maintain a central leader, and unnecessary pruning should be avoided to preserve the tree's natural shape. As a versatile plant, it can adapt to various lighting conditions, but maximizing sunlight exposure will yield the best flowering results and overall plant vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pycnanthemum albescens helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Perform light pruning in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems from the previous growing season. During the growing season, you may also pinch back the growing tips to promote branching and a more compact form. After the plant has finished blooming, shearing it back by about one-third can tidy its appearance and may encourage a flush of new growth. Pinch back the tips of the stems in early spring to encourage branching and a fuller plant. After the blooming period, typically cut back spent flowers to tidy up its appearance and prevent excessive self-seeding. Remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the growing season to promote air circulation and reduce disease risk. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15544,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus mugo is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering. Water newly planted pines regularly during their first growing season to establish a strong root system. Once established, the mugo pine should only be watered during prolonged dry periods, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot and other diseases. It's important to ensure the soil dries out between waterings. Deep, infrequent watering encourages deep root growth, enhancing drought resistance. In areas with natural rainfall, supplemental watering may not be necessary once the plant is established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus mugo thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure ensures the best growth and encourages the plant's naturally dense form. In shaded areas, it may become more open and less compact. Providing adequate sunlight also helps the plant resist pests and diseases. If planted in a garden setting, consider siting it on the south or west side of the landscape for maximum sunlight exposure throughout the day. Adequate light is essential for its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus mugo should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth emerges, to maintain its shape and encourage density. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to promote healthy growth. To control size or shape, cut back the new growth, also known as candles, by about two-thirds. Avoid cutting into the older, bare wood, as this can lead to bare patches. Regular maintenance will help maintain a compact and attractive form. It's also important to sterilize pruning tools before use to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mountain pine","description":"Pinus mugo, known as creeping pine, dwarf mountainpine, mugo pine, mountain pine, scrub mountain pine or Swiss mountain pine, is a species of conifer, native to high elevation habitats from southwestern to Central Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central Europe","Southern Europe"],"other_name":["mountain pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pine sawfly","Aphids","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus mugo"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In lower light conditions, though this plant can adapt, it may become less dense and more leggy, indicating it needs more light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asparagus densiflorus is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging new growth. Trim back any brown or yellowing stems, as these are often indicators of old or damaged foliage. Use clean, sharp scissors to cut these stems back to the base. Regular pruning can also prevent the plant from becoming too leggy or overgrown. Additionally, removing old stems can help to rejuvenate the plant and promote more bushy growth. Prune during the growing season when the plant is actively producing new shoots for the best results."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sprenger's Asparagus","description":"Asparagus densiflorus (asparagus fern, plume asparagus, foxtail fern) is an evergreen perennial plant, closely related to the vegetable asparagus, and native to southern Africa from Mozambique to South Africa. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15940,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dipodium roseum, also known as the Pink Hyacinth Orchid, prefers to be kept slightly moist but not waterlogged. Natural rainfall is often sufficient, especially in areas that mimic its native habitat. During dry spells, providing additional water can help maintain the plant’s vitality, but it is essential to let the medium dry out somewhat between watering to prevent root rot. Over-watering can be detrimental, as the root system is quite sensitive. Adjust the watering schedule based on humidity levels and temperature, ensuring that the soil or medium is well-draining."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dipodium roseum thrives in dappled sunlight, simulating its natural environment under the canopy of trees. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, excessive exposure can lead to leaf scorch or damage. It is best suited to a position that receives bright, indirect light for most of the day. If grown indoors, placing it near a window with filtered light or in partial shade can replicate the conditions it prefers. Avoid deep shade as it may hinder growth and flowering. Adjust its position based on light intensity to prevent stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dipodium roseum is generally minimal, as this species does not have extensive foliage or branching habits typical of other garden plants. Remove any spent flower spikes or dead foliage to maintain a tidy appearance and reduce the risk of pest infestation or disease. This should be done carefully to avoid damaging the naturally growing parts of the plant. Use clean, sterilized tools to prevent the spread of pathogens. Proper care and minimal disturbance are all that’s needed to keep Dipodium roseum healthy and thriving."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rosy Hyacinth Orchid","description":"Dipodium roseum, commonly known as rosy hyacinth-orchid or pink hyacinth-orchid, is a leafless mycoheterotrophic orchid found in east and south-eastern Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Rosy Hyacinth Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Dipodium roseum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16032,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aquilegia flavescens prefer consistently moist soil, but they should not be over-watered as they are susceptible to root rot. During the growing season, water them regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, allowing the top inch to dry out between waterings. Reduce watering frequency in the fall as the plants go dormant. Adjust the watering cycle based on the climate and weather conditions; for instance, rainy periods require less supplementary watering. Ensure the planting site has good drainage to prevent water-logged conditions that could harm the plant’s roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aquilegia flavescens thrive best in partial shade, where they receive light that is filtered or only direct for a few hours a day. Full sun exposure can cause stress, especially in hotter climates, leading to wilting and reduced flowering. However, in cooler climates, they can tolerate more sun and might even perform well with full morning sun exposure. If planted in too much shade, the plants might grow leggy and produce fewer flowers. It’s essential to balance the light exposure based on the climate to optimize growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aquilegia flavescens can help maintain its health and appearance. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage new blooms and prevent unwanted self-seeding, which can lead to an excessive number of seedlings. After the flowering season, prune back the foliage as it starts to look ragged or unhealthy, which allows for rejuvenation and better growth in the next season. Cut the stems down to about a few inches above the base. Always use clean and sharp tools to prevent any disease spread. Remove dead or diseased leaves throughout the growing season to keep the plant healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"yellow columbine","description":"Aquilegia flavescens, the yellow columbine, is a wildflower native to mountain meadows, open woods, and alpine slopes of the Rocky Mountains from Utah north to British Columbia and Alberta.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["yellow columbine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aquilegia flavescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15348,"attracts":["Birds","Hoary Edge"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Persea borbonia prefers consistently moist soil and should be watered regularly, especially during dry periods. It's important to provide enough water to keep the roots moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to root rot. During the growing season, increase the frequency of watering to support new growth, but be mindful of allowing the top inch of soil to dry slightly between waterings. In cooler months, reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure adequate drainage in the planting site or container to prevent standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Persea borbonia thrives in full sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth, provide the plant with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. However, in extremely hot climates, some protection from the harsh afternoon sun can be beneficial. If grown in a shaded area, expect slower growth and less dense foliage. Full sun exposure encourages robust growth and a healthier appearance, so if possible, plant it in a location where it receives morning sunlight and some afternoon shade, especially during peak summer months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Persea borbonia should be done to maintain a desired shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any crossed or inward-growing branches to improve air circulation and overall plant health. Light trimming will help the tree maintain its natural form and can encourage denser foliage. Ensure that your tools are clean and sharp to avoid damaging the plant tissue, and sterilize them if removing diseased branches to prevent spreading disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"redbay","description":"Persea borbonia is a species of plant in the Lauraceae family, with several common names including redbay, tisswood, scrubbay, shorebay, and swampbay.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Cuba"],"other_name":["redbay"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Persea borbonia"],"soil":["Acidic","Moist","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15744,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sempervivum montanum, commonly known as mountain houseleek, is a drought-tolerant succulent that requires minimal watering. It thrives in well-draining soil and dry conditions. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings, which typically means once every two to three weeks. Overwatering is the most common issue and can lead to root rot. During winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering even further. Ensure any excess water is able to drain away to prevent waterlogged soil, which is critical for the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sempervivum montanum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate direct sun exposure for several hours a day. Ideally, place the plant in a location where it receives at least six hours of sunlight per day. Morning sunlight is preferable as it is less intense, reducing the risk of leaf scorch. If growing indoors, position the plant near a south or east-facing window. Be cautious of intense afternoon sun, especially in hotter climates, as this can potentially damage the leaves. In lower light conditions, the plant may become leggy and lose its compact form."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sempervivum montanum is minimal but necessary to maintain its health and appearance. Remove dead, dying, or damaged leaves regularly, especially the outer rosettes, to promote air circulation and prevent rot. After the plant flowers, the flowering rosette will die, and it should be trimmed back to direct energy to new offsets. Using clean, sharp scissors or garden shears, simply cut away the dead rosettes at their base. This also prevents any potential pest infestation. Regularly removing dead foliage ensures the plant remains tidy and encourages the growth of new rosettes."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mountain Houseleek","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Alps"],"other_name":["Mountain Houseleek"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Sempervivum montanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14353,"attracts":["Birds","Squirrels"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus stellata, commonly known as post oak, is a drought-tolerant tree that requires minimal watering once it is established. During its first growing season, it should be watered regularly to help it establish a strong root system, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. After establishment, supplemental watering is generally unnecessary unless there are prolonged periods of drought. In such cases, deep watering once every few weeks can help. It’s important to avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot and other water-related issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus stellata thrives in full sun, which means it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and health. This oak species is well-adapted to sunny environments and can tolerate hot, sunny conditions once established. It can also survive in partial shade, but this might lead to a less dense foliage and reduced overall vigor. Planting it in a location where it can soak in ample sunlight will help it develop a strong structure and enhance its resistance to pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus stellata should be done primarily to remove dead, diseased, or broken branches. Ideally, this should be done during the late winter or early spring while the tree is still dormant to reduce stress and prevent sap loss. Light pruning can also help shape young trees and enhance structural strength. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this can lead to significant water loss and stress. If reducing size is necessary, prune back the previous year's growth by about one-third. During hot or dry conditions, increase watering frequency to prevent the soil from drying out completely. Make sure the plant has good drainage to avoid waterlogged roots, as overwatering can lead to root rot. Reducing the watering frequency in its dormancy stage during late summer and winter is beneficial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola striata thrives in partial to full shade, making it ideal for woodland gardens or shaded areas of your yard. While it can tolerate some morning sunlight, it is crucial to protect it from harsh midday and afternoon sun, which can scorch its delicate leaves. In regions with cooler climates, Violas can endure more dappled sunlight, while in hotter areas, they require more protection and shade. When planting, consider the natural habitat of moist, shaded undergrowth to ensure optimal conditions. Providing adequate shade helps maintain soil moisture, crucial for the plant’s health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viola striata is minimal but necessary to maintain its health and appearance. As the growing season ends, trim back any damaged or yellowing leaves to improve air circulation around the plant. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season as this can stress the plant unnecessarily."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"cream violet","description":"Viola striata is a species of violet known by the common names striped cream violet and creamy violet. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15249,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhinanthus alectorolophus, commonly known as Yellow Rattle, is a semi-parasitic wildflower and does not have the same watering needs as typical garden plants. It derives some nutrients and water from nearby grasses, so additional watering is usually unnecessary unless you are establishing it in a garden setting. In such cases, water the plant moderately, ensuring the soil is well-draining and not overly moist. Avoid waterlogging the area as this can damage the plant. Once established, natural rainfall should largely suffice, especially in areas with moderate rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhinanthus alectorolophus thrives in full sun to partial shade. It grows best in meadows, grasslands, or open woodland areas where it can receive ample sunlight. Position your plant in a location with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. In partial shade, it may still survive, but growth and flowering might be less vigorous. When planting in a garden, try to mimic its natural habitat for best results. Ensure that the surrounding grasses don't overshadow it to maintain its health and vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Rhinanthus alectorolophus is minimal and primarily involves ensuring the plant does not spread uncontrollably. As an annual, it does not require regular pruning like perennial plants. It self-seeds, and you may choose to remove seed heads before they mature to control its propagation if it’s in a garden setting. Deadheading may also promote a tidier appearance, although it will naturally die back at the end of the growing season. Enjoy its yellow blooms and monitor its growth to keep it in check if needed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Greater Yellow Rattle","description":"Rhinanthus alectorolophus, the European yellow-rattle, is a plant species of the genus Rhinanthus, native to Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Greater Yellow Rattle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Rhinanthus alectorolophus"],"soil":["Dry","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14354,"attracts":["Birds","Squirrels"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus michauxii, or swamp chestnut oak, prefers moist environments typical of its native habitats. It does best with soil that is consistently moist but not waterlogged. During dry periods, regular watering will help maintain its health, especially for young trees still establishing roots. Ensure water deeply reaches the root system, mimicking the tree's natural floodplain conditions. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. In general, more established trees are drought-tolerant, but supplemental watering during prolonged dry spells is beneficial for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus michauxii thrives in full sun, where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. While it is also able to tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and acorn production are achieved with more sunlight. Placing the tree in a location with good sunlight exposure is ideal, as this mimics the tree's natural environment within floodplains and bottomlands. When grown in shaded areas, the tree may exhibit slower growth and become more susceptible to pests and diseases. Providing ample sunlight ensures robust development and a healthy canopy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Quercus michauxii should focus on maintaining a strong structure and removing any dead, diseased, or crossing branches. Prune the tree during its dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This minimizes stress and potential pest or disease intrusion. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can reduce the tree's vigor. Remove suckers and water sprouts routinely to direct energy to the main canopy. Regularly check for deadwood and damaged limbs, especially after storms, to keep the tree healthy and aesthetically pleasing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"swamp chestnut oak","description":"Quercus michauxii, the swamp chestnut oak, is a species of oak in the white oak section Quercus section Quercus in the beech family. Once established, Coreopsis tripteris is quite drought-tolerant and can survive on rainfall alone, requiring watering only during prolonged dry spells. Ensure it is not planted in areas that are heavily shaded as it will lead to sparse flowering and leggy growth, diminishing its overall vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coreopsis tripteris is essential for maintaining its appearance and encouraging bushy growth. Deadheading spent flowers throughout the blooming period will prolong flowering. In late fall, once flowering has ceased, cut back the stems to about 6 inches above ground level. This cleanup helps prevent pests and diseases and prepares the plant for winter dormancy. In spring, remove any dead or damaged growth to encourage new shoots. Pruning also helps control the plant's height and prevents it from becoming too leggy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"tall coreopsis","description":"Coreopsis tripteris is a North American species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. It is widespread across much of eastern and central North America from the Florida Panhandle west as far as eastern Texas and north to Québec and Ontario. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14452,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oclemena acuminata, commonly known as whorled wood aster, prefers consistently moist soils, so it is important to water it regularly. However, it should never be waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. The key is to maintain an evenly damp environment, especially during dry spells. Mulching can help keep the soil moist and reduce the need for frequent watering. During periods of active growth, monitor the soil moisture closely, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Avoid letting the plant dry out completely, especially under hot and sunny conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oclemena acuminata prefers partial to full shade conditions, making it an ideal plant for woodland gardens or areas with dappled sunlight. It thrives under forest canopies where it receives filtered sunlight throughout the day. Direct, harsh sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves and affect the plant’s overall health. If planted in a sunnier location, ensure it receives some afternoon shade to prevent heat stress. The plant can tolerate more sun with adequate soil moisture, but it will perform best in shadier conditions. Adjust its location based on its growth and flowering response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oclemena acuminata generally involves removing spent flowers and any damaged or dead foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. This is best done in late autumn or early spring. Trim back dead flower stems to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy appearance. Avoid cutting the plant back entirely during the growing season as it may affect its ability to flower. Light pruning helps promote a bushier plant and encourages fuller blooms. Maintain good air circulation around the plant by thinning crowded stems to prevent fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"whorled wood aster","description":"Oclemena acuminata, commonly known as whorled wood aster, is a plant native to eastern North America. Its range extends from Newfoundland to Georgia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["whorled wood aster"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Oclemena acuminata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

They are drought-tolerant and prefer less frequent watering, particularly if planted in a native or xeriscape garden. Water the plant during extended dry spells, ensuring that the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, especially if the soil has poor drainage. Aim to water early in the morning or late in the afternoon to minimize evaporation and prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant is adapted to high-altitude, sunny conditions, making full sun the ideal lighting for Castilleja parviflora. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to thrive. Planting in a location that offers full sun exposure will enhance its vivid blooms and overall health. However, in regions with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the plant from becoming scorched or dehydrated. Place the plant where it can receive ample sunlight, ensuring vigorous growth and vibrant flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Castilleja parviflora is generally minimal and should be done lightly to maintain its natural shape. Trim away any dead or damaged stems after flowering to encourage new growth and maintain plant health. Remove spent blooms to possibly promote a longer blooming period. When pruning, use clean, sharp tools to avoid causing damage to the plant. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant and potentially disrupt its role as a hemiparasite, reliant on nearby host plants for nutrients."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Indian Paintbrush","description":"Castilleja parviflora is a species of Indian paintbrush known by the common name mountain Indian paintbrush. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14251,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Marasmius oreades, often known as the fairy ring mushroom, does not require watering as it is a type of fungi, not a plant meant for traditional horticulture. In its natural setting, it thrives in moist environments which support its growth on decaying organic matter. If attempting cultivation, maintain a humid atmosphere but avoid direct watering as mushrooms absorb water from the air rather than through direct contact. High humidity levels typically between 85-90% are ideal to ensure the necessary moisture conditions to promote its growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Marasmius oreades mushrooms prefer environments with indirect light rather than direct sunlight. Although they are capable of growing in a variety of light conditions, high levels of direct sunlight can dry out the growth medium and hinder the moisture levels necessary for their development. Ideally, these mushrooms thrive in shaded or partially shaded areas where moisture levels remain consistent. If cultivating indoors, place them in environments mimicking these natural conditions, such as under trees or within structured shade setups, while maintaining an even, humid environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Marasmius oreades as they are fungi and not traditional plants that require shaping or trimming. However, monitoring and removing old or decaying mushrooms can be beneficial if trying to encourage a new crop to form. Ensuring dead material is cleared can reduce the chances of mold and ensure optimal conditions for new fungal fruit bodies. In natural settings, there's no need for human intervention; they self-regulate according to their environmental conditions."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fairy ring marasmius","description":"Marasmius oreades, the Scotch bonnet, is also known as the fairy ring mushroom or fairy ring champignon. The latter names tend to cause some confusion, as many other mushrooms grow in fairy rings (such as the edible Agaricus campestris, the poisonous Chlorophyllum molybdites, and many others).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["fairy ring marasmius"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Marasmius oreades"],"soil":[],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
